   Assessment and Plan
   81M with ischemic heart dz EF 30%, p/w septic shock and multiorgan
   failure from CAP PNA complicated by VAP, currently on HD with c diff
   colitis on PO vanc and IV flagyl and  HAP GNR with ceftriaxone.
   PLAN:
   .
   Leukocytosis/fever
 progressive since [**4-5**], spiked last two nights
   blood culture NTD, urine showed yeast, sputum showing pansensitive
   serratia and KLEBSIELLA OXYTOCA initially colonized and secondarily
   infected on [**4-7**].  Had positive c.diff [**4-8**] in the setting of prolonged
   antibiotic administration. For the repeat PNA on the [**4-7**], there were
   not significant radiographic findings, but with increased secretions
   and needing to be placed back on the vent, started treating for HAP
   with vanco/zosyn, until [**4-10**], when repeat sputum cultures showed GNR
   and stopped vanco and switched zosyn to meropenem. KUB did not show any
   evidence of megacolon. Also will consider non-tunnelled line as source.
   Other source as of [**4-10**] could be from foley, since oliguric, d/c foley
   and will straight cath as needed.
   - consider thoracentesis to evaluate pleural effusion for empyema
   - treat HAP serratia and klebsiella 8day course ending [**2167-4-15**] was on
   ceftriaxone, currently on meropenem [**4-13**] due to CTX interaction with
   CVVH
   - treat c.diff with PO vanco and IV flagyl 14 days after PNA abx
   stopped -> flagyl changed to TID
   - lactates stable at 2.2
   - ID c/s for persistent fever
   - F/u beta-glucan, galactomannin for persistent yeast in urine
   .
   Septic Shock/Hypotension:   Initially hypotensive in setting of septic
   shock.  Had Early Goal Directed Therapy with Apache IV score of 114.
   Initial sputum with GNRs and GPCs in pairs.  Initial PNA treated.  Then
   patient developed what is thought to be VAP, treated until [**4-1**].  He
   was doing well until lsat two days when BPs started to trend downward.
   Thought to possibly due to ativan.  Now with more information, due to
   sepsis from c.diff (see above for infection discussion).  Had SBPs in
   the 50s/30s and change in mental status overnight.
   - Tried dopamine, but weaned off
   - continue IVF resuscitation
   - trend lactates as end measure of end organ perfusion - stable
   - on CVVH
   - Started midodrine 10mg TID for pressure support in attempt to wean
   Levophed
   .
   VAP PNA/ Resp failure/ ARDS: from VAP from retained partial dentures.
   Likely due to pulmonary infiltrates.  Patient with elevated WBC counts
   and infiltrates on CXR. ARDS secondary to PNA. Initially improving and
   now worsening because of possible VAP. Zosyn and meropenem stopped
   [**3-26**]. restarted meropenem on [**3-28**] bc worsening hypotension and sepsis
   -Patient has been on Vancomycin. Tobramycin was discontinued on [**3-26**]
   but given worsening of patient, tobra restarted [**3-27**] for likely VAP.
   VAP grew out citrobacter freundii sensitive to tobra/meropenem. Repeat
   cultures same citrobacter. Differential includes leukocytosis caused by
   infected HD line in femoral vein, see below. Completed 8 day course of
   tobra/meropenem. Patient trached on [**4-1**] and failed PEG. Patient went
   to OR on [**4-3**] for open G-tube placement.  Was doing well on trach mask
   trial until [**4-9**] when he was tachypneic and tiring.
   - intermittent trach mask trials as tolerated, supplemented by PSV PRN
 able totolerate a few hours before tiring
   - treat new HAP as above with 8-day course of ABX (Ceftriaxone ->
   meropenem) ending [**2167-4-15**], follow up cultures
   - F/u mixed venous gas
   - F/u new Gram neg sensitivities
   .
   Anemia
 severe anemia, patient is DAT (super Coombs positive), has
   many antibodies and will hemolyze donor blood. Should only transfuse in
   emergency settings of active ischemia. Patient has anemia of chronic
   disease, will not benefit from Iron. Folate nl, B12 high, evidence of
   hemolysis bc low hapto high LDH. Appropriate reticulocytosis.
   - heme following
   - F/u hemolysis labs
   - Add Procrit
   - Add Fe++ po
   .
   LUE swelling
 could be in setting of thrombosis from pacer wires
   - LENI is negative, stable
   .
   Dysphonia
 due to cuffed 8.0 trach, will change on [**4-13**] and then get
   ENT consult as needed as outpatient, confirmed with ENT and IP on
   [**2167-4-7**]. Got PMV on [**4-6**].
   - Will hold off until resp status improves
   .
   Coagulopathy: improving, Appears to be have been caused by shock liver.
   Platelets stable, no evidence of DIC. Given vitamin [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 8155**] [**4-4**].
   Continues to improve with slowly decreasing INR.
   - following daily
   - stool guaiac negative
   Transaminitis: Likely due to shock liver in setting of distributive
   picture with decreased EF. RUQ u/s shows known CBD dialation, s/p
   chole. LFT
s improving.
   .
   Oliguric, acute on chronic ARF/Uremia: Baseline Cr 2.3.  Patient in ARF
   from acute tubular necrosis in setting of hypotension.  Patient was
   given CVVH through L femoral line then HD. Renal pulled fem HD line
   with resolution of leukocytosis, tip culture pending, but could suggest
   line infection. [**3-31**], placed IR HD line on Tuesday with VIP port,
   non-tunneled since was spiking.
   - holding HD today in setting of acute infection, continue to follow up
   renal recs. Since patient on pressors since [**4-8**] in the setting of c
   diff sepsis and VAP, renal restarted CVVH on [**4-10**].
   -  renal giving EPO
   - No placement of tunneled HD line as pos blood cultures
   .
   Mental Status: awake, following commands. Initially, mental status did
   not immediately return once sedation removed because of shock liver and
   decreased metabolism of sedatives on initial presentation.
   -          MS much improved, cont zyprexa as needed for agitation
   .
   CV: this does not appear to be ACS, although CK markedly elevated.

   hypotension
   CAD: CABG [**2146**] with multiple PCI.  Continue ASA, statin, re-start BB

   PUMP: EF 29%.  Off of pressors, rpt echo EF 25%
   RHYTHM: CHB s/p DDD PCM,ICD in [**2160**]. Not on Warfarin.

 tube feeds thru G tube

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease, who presented with septic shock and multiorgan failure due to pneumonia (PNA) complicated by ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). He also had Clostridium difficile (C. diff) colitis, hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) caused by Gram-negative rods (GNR), and a urinary tract infection (UTI) with yeast. The patient's condition has been complicated by various medical issues, including severe anemia, thrombosis, dysphonia, coagulopathy, transaminitis, oliguric acute on chronic renal failure/uremia, and hypoalbuminemia.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Leukocytosis/Fever: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count indicate an ongoing infection. Further investigation and treatment are necessary.
2. Hypotension/Septric Shock: The patient's persistent hypotension and septic shock may be due to ongoing infection and inadequate perfusion. Close monitoring and appropriate interventions are required.
3. Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP): The patient's worsening respiratory status and positive cultures for GNR suggest VAP. Treatment with appropriate antibiotics and consideration of non-tunnelled line as a source are important.
4. Clostridium difficile (C. diff) Colitis: The patient's recent antibiotic administration and positive test for C. diff indicate

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease and a low ejection fraction (EF 30%). He presented with septic shock and multiorgan failure due to community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) complicated by ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), currently on continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVH) with Clostridium difficile colitis. He has been treated with various antibiotics for different infections, including ceftriaxone, erythromycin, metronidazole, and meropenem. The patient also has severe anemia, likely due to autoimmune hemolysis, and is unable to tolerate blood transfusions. He has been on pressors for hypotension and has had multiple episodes of hypotension and sepsis. There are concerns about possible line infections and the source of infection, with suggestions of a non-tunnelled line or Foley catheter. The patient's respiratory status has been worsening, and he has developed acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) secondary to pneumonia. He has had multiple central venous catheters, including a right internal jugular (RIJ) catheter, and has had a tracheostomy tube. He is currently on mechanical ventilation with a tracheostomy tube.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient has had multiple episodes of sepsis due to various infections, including CAP, VAP, and C.

Based on the information provided in the progress note, there are several potential medical complications that can arise for this patient. Some of these complications include:

1. Septic Shock/Hypotension: The patient initially presented with septic shock, which is a life-threatening condition characterized by low blood pressure, inadequate tissue perfusion, and organ dysfunction. The patient required early goal-directed therapy and was treated with antibiotics, vasopressors, and CVVH.

2. Clostridium difficile (C. diff) infection: The patient has been diagnosed with C. diff colitis, which is a bacterial infection that causes severe diarrhea and colitis. This infection is commonly associated with antibiotic use and can lead to significant morbidity and mortality if not treated appropriately.

3. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient has developed VAP, which is a type of lung infection that occurs in individuals who are receiving mechanical ventilation. VAP can be challenging to treat and may require prolonged antibiotic therapy.

4. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient has evidence of AKI, characterized by an increase in serum creatinine levels and oliguria (low urine output). AKI can be caused by hypotension, sepsis, or direct kidney injury.

5. Anemia: The patient has severe anemia, likely due to chronic disease, and is DAT positive with many antibodies. This suggests that the patient may have an autoimmune hemolytic anemia, which can

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 64-year-old male admitted to the ICU with multiple medical conditions, including chronic heart failure, chronic renal failure, malnutrition, anxiety, impaired muscle performance, impaired balance, and impaired aerobic capacity. The patient's chief complaint is an abdominal pain. The CT scan of the torso/abdomen shows fluid and air collection associated with the duodenum and head of the pancreas, which raises concerns about a possible perforated duodenal diverticulum or pancreatic pseudocyst with superinfection. Surgery has been consulted.

The patient has received several antibiotic treatments, including ceftriaxone, erythromycin, meropenem, fluconazole, and metronidazole. He is currently on norepinephrine infusion and other ICU medications such as famotidine, morphine sulfate, and heparin sodium.

The patient's vital signs show hypotension and tachycardia. His respiratory support includes a tracheostomy tube with controlled mechanical ventilation (CMV) mode. Laboratory results indicate elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin and hematocrit levels, elevated potassium and lactate levels, and abnormalities in liver function tests.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient's elevated white blood cell count, tachycardia, and hypotension may indicate an ongoing infection, leading to sepsis.
2. Renal failure: The patient's

Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease and an ejection fraction of 30%, presenting with septic shock and multiorgan failure from pneumonia complicated by ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). He is currently on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) with Clostridium difficile colitis on PO vancomycin and IV flagyl; on ceftriaxone for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP). 

The patient has leukocytosis/fever, and the lactate level is elevated, indicating decreased end-organ perfusion. He is being treated with early goal-directed therapy and is on Levophed to maintain blood pressure. The healthcare team plans to continue CVVH even while needing pressors and will attempt to wean Levophed. 

The patient also has severe anemia due to autoimmune hemolytic anemia, and blood transfusion should only be given in emergency settings of active ischemia. He has anemia of chronic disease, and it is recommended to continue Procrit and iron supplementation. 

The patient's dysphonia is caused by a cuffed tracheostomy tube, and the healthcare team will hold off changing to a smaller cuff until respiratory status improves. 

The patient's coagulopathy is improving, likely due to shock liver. Vitamin K supplementation has been given, and the healthcare team will continue to monitor the patient's coagulation profile.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of chronic heart failure, chronic renal failure, and other comorbidities. He was admitted to the ICU due to septic shock caused by Clostridium difficile (C. diff) infection. The patient remains on mechanical ventilation and continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) for acute kidney injury.

The patient's vital signs are unstable, with low blood pressure and tachycardia. He has a fever and increased lactate levels, indicating ongoing sepsis. His mental status is altered, and he is agitated and delirious.

Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, elevated creatinine levels, and low hemoglobin. Blood cultures have been obtained to guide further antibiotic therapy. Imaging studies reveal cardiomegaly and patchy airspace disease on chest X-ray.

The patient's plan includes managing septic shock with levophed, TBB even, antibiotics, and follow-up cultures. There is concern about rising lactate levels, which may require the addition of vasopressin if levo >0.15. The team will attempt to wean levophed while on CVVH and accept a systolic blood pressure >80 mmHg and mean arterial pressure >50 mmHg. Polysomnography (PSV) trials will be tried, and antibiotics will be continued for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), to be discontinued today.

Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease, ejection fraction 30%, presenting with septic shock and multiorgan failure from community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) complicated by ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). He is currently on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) with Clostridium difficile colitis, on PO vancomycin and IV metronidazole, and on meropenem for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP). 

The patient has leukocytosis/fever, hypotension, ARDS, severe anemia, dysphonia due to a cuffed tracheostomy tube, improving coagulopathy, transaminitis, oliguric acute on chronic renal failure, and hypoalbuminemia. 

The patient's medical history includes CABG in 2146 with multiple PCI, CHF with an EF of 29%, and DDD pacemaker with ICD implanted in 2160. He is not on warfarin. 

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 35.8°C, heart rate of 77 bpm, blood pressure of 83/45 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on ventilator support. 

The patient's recent laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, elevated lactate levels, elevated creatinine levels, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelet count

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease, who presented with septic shock and multiorgan failure due to community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) complicated by ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient is currently on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) with Clostridium difficile colitis on oral vancomycin and IV metronidazole; on meropenem for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP).

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a blood pressure of 108/48 mmHg, heart rate of 78 bpm, respiratory rate of 27 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on supplemental oxygen. The patient's mixed venous oxygen saturation is 96%, which may be erroneous. The patient is receiving norepinephrine at 0.12 mcg/kg/min to maintain blood pressure.

The patient has leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 21.8 K/uL and fever. The patient is afebrile overnight. A CT scan of the abdomen revealed a fluid/air collection in the duodenum adjacent to the pancreas, which could be an abscess. The patient has been started on fluconazole for fungal coverage.

The patient's coagulopathy appears to be caused by shock liver, with an elevated prothrombin time (PT) of 27

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with a history of chronic systolic heart failure, chronic renal failure, anemia, impaired skin integrity, anxiety, impaired aerobic capacity/endurance, impaired balance, impaired muscle performance, impaired transfers, impaired ventilation, altered mental status (not delirium), malnutrition, hyperglycemia, severe sepsis with organ dysfunction, and ARDS. The patient is currently in the ICU for further management. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Coagulopathy: The patient has a high INR value indicating a bleeding risk. Close monitoring of coagulation parameters and appropriate measures to prevent bleeding events should be taken.
2. Clostridium difficile infection (C. diff): The patient's history of recent antibiotic use increases the risk for C. diff infection. Monitoring for symptoms such as diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever is essential.
3. Chronic heart failure exacerbation: The patient's chronic heart failure may worsen due to fluid overload or other contributing factors. Regular monitoring of vital signs and fluid balance is necessary.
4. Hemolytic anemia: The patient's low hemoglobin level suggests anemia. Further evaluation to determine the cause and appropriate management is required.
5. Impaired skin integrity: The patient's impaired skin integrity puts him at risk for pressure ulcers. Frequent repositioning, proper skin care, and use of pressure-relieving devices are crucial.
6. Hypotension

Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease, presenting with septic shock, multiorgan failure, and complications including c. diff colitis, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and a fungal abdominal abscess. The patient's condition has been complex and requires careful management of various medical complications.

1. Septic Shock: The patient initially presented with septic shock, which required early goal-directed therapy. Despite this, the patient remains hypotensive, and there is an ongoing concern for both septic and cardiogenic shock. The mixed venous O2 saturation is low at 52%, indicating poor tissue perfusion. Consideration should be given to the use of inotropes to increase cardiac contractility, especially if levophed requirement increases. Vasopressin may also be considered in this scenario. Gentle diuresis should be continued, but limited by low blood pressure.

2. Respiratory Failure/ARDS: The patient has ARDS secondary to PNA, requiring mechanical ventilation. Pressure support ventilation trials should be continued as tolerated. 

3. Oliguric, Acute on Chronic ARF/Uremia: The patient is experiencing acute renal failure on top of chronic renal failure, likely due to hypotension and acute tubular necrosis. CVVH is currently being used for renal support. Renal function should be closely monitored, and the patient should continue to receive erythropoietin (EPO).

4. Anemia: The patient has severe anemia, most likely due to chronic disease and hemolysis. Only emergency transfusions should be given in settings of active ischemia. The patient also has antibodies against donor blood, so blood transfusions should be limited. Folate supplementation should be increased.

5. Coagulopathy: The patient appears to have a coagulopathy likely caused by shock liver and subacute disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). The platelet count is decreasing, and the INR is increasing. The patient is also positive for heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). If coagulation parameters normalize, Argatroban may be considered as an anticoagulant.

6. Transaminitis: The patient has transaminitis likely due to shock liver. RUQ ultrasound shows known common bile duct dilation, which is stable.

7. Dysphonia: The patient has dysphonia due to a cuffed tracheostomy tube. The cuff size should be reduced once respiratory status improves.

8. Mental Status: The patient is alert and oriented but can be delirious at times. Frequent reorientation and maintaining a sleep-wake cycle are recommended.

9. Cardiovascular: The patient's cardiovascular system is stable. CK levels are elevated due to hypovolemia and shock. No ischemic EKG changes have been noted.

10. CABG: The patient underwent coronary artery bypass graft

Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease, presenting with septic shock and multiorgan failure secondary to community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) complicated by ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). He has been diagnosed with a fungal upper abdominal abscess, for which he is being treated with fluconazole. The patient is also suffering from Clostridium difficile colitis and has been on vancomycin and metronidazole. He has been on meropenem for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) due to pansensitive Serratia and Klebsiella. The patient's vital signs are unstable, and he requires norepinephrine to maintain blood pressure. He is on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) due to acute kidney injury (AKI). The patient has severe anemia with positive direct antiglobulin test (DAT) and will only be transfused in emergency settings. He is also experiencing coagulopathy with elevated INR and PTT, likely due to subacute disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). The patient's mental status is fluctuating between alertness and delirium. His cardiac function is compromised with an ejection fraction (EF) of 29%. He has a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), with previous coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) and percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). He also has a pacemaker and implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD). The patient is currently admitted to the medical intensive care unit (MICU). 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Septic shock: The patient is already experiencing septic shock, which can lead to multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS).
2. Multiorgan failure: The patient has already developed multiorgan failure, including respiratory, renal, hepatic, and hematological dysfunction.
3. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's CAP has complicated into VAP, which can increase the risk of mortality.
4. Fungal infection: The patient has a fungal upper abdominal abscess, and there is a risk of further dissemination or development of antifungal resistance.
5. Clostridium difficile colitis: The patient is being treated for C. difficile colitis, and there is a risk of recurrence or complications such as toxic megacolon.
6. Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP): The patient has developed HAP, which can be caused by drug-resistant organisms and may be difficult to treat.
7. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient is experiencing AKI, which can progress to chronic kidney disease (CKD) if not managed appropriately.
8. Anemia: The patient has severe anemia, and ongoing blood loss or inadequate production of red blood cells may worsen his condition.
9. Coagulopathy: The patient

The patient has been in the ICU for several weeks, experiencing various medical complications.

3. Oliguric, acute on chronic ARF/Uremia: The patient is in acute renal failure from acute tubular necrosis in the setting of hypotension. He is currently on CVVH. Renal function should be closely monitored, and appropriate recommendations from the hematology team should be followed.

   Had Early Goal Directed Therapy with Apache IV score of 114.  PNA, C.
   diff, intra-abdominal abcess are likely sources. Levophed requirement
   increasing to maintain BP. Shock may be both septic and cardiogenic (pt
   has ischemic heart disease with EF 20-30%).
   - mixed venous O2 sat was rechecked- 52%
   - Consider use of inotropes to increase cardiac contractility- if
   levophed requirement goes up, add vasopressin.
   - on CVVH; try gentle diuresis of 50cc neg/hr since pt is extremely
   volume overloaded (however limited by low BP) Consider increasing
   levophed to allow for more aggressive diuresis.
   - Continue midodrine 10mg TID
   .
   Resp failure/ ARDS: ARDS secondary to PNA. Patient trached on [**4-1**]. On
   Vent, Assist Control
   - Pressure support ventilation trials as tolerated.
   .
   Oliguric, acute on chronic ARF/Uremia: Baseline Cr 2.3.  Patient in ARF
   from acute tubular necrosis in setting of hypotension.  Pt on CVVH at
   this time.
   - Renal following, appreciate recs
   - Continue EPO
   Anemia
 severe anemia, patient is DAT (super Coombs positive), has
   many antibodies and will hemolyze donor blood. Should only transfuse in
   emergency settings of active ischemia. Patient has anemia of chronic
   disease, limited benefit from iron supp, but little harm to give it.
   Folate nl, B12 high, evidence of hemolysis b/c low hapto, high LDH,
   high D Bili. Appropriate reticulocytosis. Patient likely has subacute
   DIC. Per Heme, blood bank has 2 U frozen for this patient.
   - transfuse 1 unit PRBCs today.
   - appreciate heme recs: check hemolysis labs daily
   - Continue Procrit, Fe++ po; increased folate 1mg to 4mg Qday
   .
   Coagulopathy: Appears to be have been caused by shock liver. Platelets
   gradually decreasing over the course of the hospital stay. INR
   increasing. Patient likely with subacute DIC. Also found to be HIT+
   yesterday. Per heme, will check serotonin release assay for
   confirmation and monitor INR/PTT.
   - F/U serotonin release assay. F/U daily coags.
   - If coags normalize, will consider starting Argatroban
   .
   Transaminitis: Likely due to shock liver in setting of distributive
   picture with decreased EF. RUQ u/s shows known CBD dialation, s/p
   chole. Stable.
   .
   Dysphonia
 due to cuffed 8.0 trach
   - Will hold off changing to smaller cuff until resp status improves
   - ENT consult as needed as outpatient, confirmed with ENT and IP on
   [**2167-4-7**]. Got PMV on [**4-6**].
   .
   Mental Status: Alert and oriented x 3, clear mentation at this time.
   Frustrated with long ICU stay and illness. [**Month (only) 60**] also be delirious at
   moments.
   - Frequent reorientation; maintain sleep-wake cycle.
   - Hold Ativan. Use  Zyprexa PRN for agitation.
   .
   CV: Stable. CK elevated in the setting of hypovolemia/shock. No
   ischemic EKG changes. .
   CAD: CABG [**2146**] with multiple PCI.  Continue ASA, statin, re-start BB
   when pressures stable.
   PUMP: EF 29%.  Off of pressors, rpt echo EF 25%
   RHYTHM: CHB s/p DDD PCM,ICD in [**2160**]. Not on Warfarin.
   -          Maintain on telemetry
   -          Maintain Hct >21, ideally >25, but issues with transfusing,
   see above.
   -          Continue midodrine
   .
   FEN
 holding tube feeds at this time. Replete lytes PRN

An IR drainage of the fluid collection was performed today after reversing INR, and the patient will likely need FFP prior to the procedure.

Potential Medical Complications:

2. Respiratory Failure/ARDS: The patient has ARDS secondary to PNA. The patient is intubated and on assist control ventilation. Pressure support ventilation trials should be attempted as tolerated.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with ischemic heart disease, presenting with septic shock and multiorgan failure secondary to CAP (pneumonia) complicated by VAP (ventilator-associated pneumonia). He has a history of c. diff colitis, upper abdominal abscess, and ARDS (acute respiratory distress syndrome). The patient is currently on CVVH (continuous veno-venous hemofiltration), receiving meropenem for VAP, fluconazole for fungal abdominal abscess, and vancomycin and IV flagyl for c. diff. He also has severe anemia, likely due to subacute DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation), and is positive for HIT (heparin-induced thrombocytopenia). The patient's mental status is alert and oriented, but he may experience delirium at times.

Potential medical complications:
1. Shock/hypotension: The patient is experiencing septic shock, which is likely both septic and cardiogenic in nature due to his ischemic heart disease. He requires Levophed and midodrine to maintain blood pressure.
2. Respiratory failure/ARDS: The patient has ARDS secondary to PNA (pneumonia). He is intubated and on assist control ventilation. Pressure support ventilation trials are being attempted as tolerated.
3. Oliguric, acute on chronic ARF/uremia: The patient is in acute renal failure

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease, who presented with septic shock and multiorgan failure secondary to community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) complicated by ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient has been diagnosed with C. difficile colitis and an upper abdominal fungal abscess. He has been treated with meropenem for pan-sensitive Serratia and Klebsiella hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP), vancomycin and metronidazole for C. difficile, and fluconazole for the fungal abscess.

Medical Complications:
1. Shock/Hypotension: The patient initially presented with hypotension in the setting of septic shock. He received early goal-directed therapy and is currently on norepinephrine and midodrine.
2. Respiratory Failure/ARDS: The patient developed acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) secondary to CAP. He is currently intubated and on assist-control ventilation. Pressure support ventilation trials are being considered as tolerated.
3. Oliguric, Acute on Chronic ARF/Uremia: The patient has acute kidney injury (AKI) due to acute tubular necrosis in the setting of hypotension. He is undergoing continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH).
4. Anemia: The patient has anemia of chronic disease with evidence of hemolysis. Repeat Coombs test was negative.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease, ejection fraction of 30%, who is currently in the ICU due to septic shock and multiorgan failure from community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) complicated by ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient has several medical complications and conditions that need attention.

1. Shock/Hypotension: The patient was initially hypotensive in the setting of septic shock. He received early goal-directed therapy with an Apache IV score of 114. The possible sources of shock include PNA, C. diff, and intra-abdominal abscess. The patient is currently on levophed and midodrine.

2. Respiratory Failure/ARDS: The patient has ARDS secondary to PNA and is tracheostomized. He is on assisted control ventilation with a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O. Pressure support ventilation trials are planned as tolerated.

3. Leukocytosis/Fever: The patient was afebrile for 48 hours, but now has fluctuating lactate levels. A CT torso showed a fluid/air collection in the duodenum adjacent to the pancreas, which was drained with interventional radiology on [**4-17**]. The gram stain showed budding yeast, indicating a fungal infection. Fluconazole was added on [**4-16**] for fungal coverage.

4. Oliguric, Acute on Chronic ARF/Uremia: The patient's baseline creatinine is 2.3, and he is in acute renal failure from acute tubular necrosis in the setting of hypotension. He is currently on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH).

5. Anemia: The patient has anemia of chronic disease with limited benefit from iron supplementation. He has evidence of hemolysis due to low haptoglobin, high lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and high total bilirubin. The direct antiglobulin test (DAT) was initially positive but negative on repeat testing. The patient should only be transfused in emergency settings of active ischemia, as he likely has subacute disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

6. Coagulopathy: The patient likely has coagulopathy due to shock liver, subacute DIC, and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). His platelets are gradually decreasing, and his international normalized ratio (INR) is increasing. He tested positive for HIT on [**4-18**]. The serotonin release assay will be checked for confirmation, and he will be monitored for INR/PTT.

7. Transaminitis: The patient has transaminitis likely due to shock liver in the setting of distributive shock with decreased ejection fraction.

   Assessment and Plan
   81M with ischemic heart dz EF 30%, p/w septic shock and multiorgan
   failure from CAP PNA complicated by VAP, currently on CVVH with c diff
   colitis on PO vanc and IV flagyl; on meropenem for VAP, fluconazole for
   fungal upper abd abcess.
   #.Leukocytosis/fever
 Pt afebrile x48h. Lactate fluctuating, currently
   3.1. CT torso showing a fluid/air collection in duodenum, adj to
   pancreas, drained with IR on [**4-17**] with pigtail placement, and gram stain
   shows budding yeast.. Fluconazole was added [**4-16**] for fungal coverage.
   Galactomannin negative; beta-glucan was cancelled due to hemolyzed
   sample.
   - On meropenem Day [**12-26**] for the latest HAP
 Pansensitive Serratia and
   Klebsiella (Was on ceftriaxone however interacts with CVVH). Plan to
   d/c meropenem today.
   - on PO vanc  and IV flagyl for c. diff (Day [**8-21**] today)
   - On Fluconazole (Day 3) for fungal abcess.
   - f/u ID recs
   - f/u surgery recs for further management upper abd abcess.
   .
   #. Shock/Hypotension:   Initially hypotensive in setting of septic
   shock.  Had Early Goal Directed Therapy with Apache IV score of 114.
   PNA, C. diff, intra-abdominal abcess are likely sources. Levophed
   requirement increasing to maintain BP. Shock may be both septic and
   cardiogenic (pt has ischemic heart disease with EF 20-30%). Currently
   on levophed and midodrine.
   - Mixed venous O2 sat was rechecked- 52%. Consider use of inotropes if
   levophed requirement increases.
   - on CVVH; try gentle diuresis of 50cc neg/hr since pt is extremely
   volume overloaded (however limited by low BP). Consider increasing
   levophed during dialysis to allow for more aggressive diuresis.
   - Once negative fluid goal met (-1 to 2L), trial weaning levophed.
   - Continue midodrine 10mg TID
   .
   #. Resp failure/ ARDS: ARDS secondary to PNA. Patient trached on [**4-1**].
   On Vent, Assist Control
   - Pressure support ventilation trials as tolerated.
   .
   #. Oliguric, acute on chronic ARF/Uremia: Baseline Cr 2.3.  Patient in
   ARF from acute tubular necrosis in setting of hypotension.  Pt on CVVH
   at this time.
   - Renal following, appreciate recs
   - Start Neutra-phos today per Renal
   - Continue EPO
   .
   #Anemia
 severe anemia, patient is DAT (super Coombs positive), has
   many antibodies and will hemolyze donor blood. Should only transfuse in
   emergency settings of active ischemia. Patient has anemia of chronic
   disease, limited benefit from iron supp, but little harm to give it.
   Folate nl, B12 high, evidence of hemolysis b/c low hapto, high LDH,
   high D Bili. Appropriate reticulocytosis. Patient likely has subacute
   DIC. Per Heme, blood bank has 2 U frozen for this patient.
   - transfuse 1 unit PRBCs today.  Post-transfusion Hct check.
   - appreciate heme recs: check hemolysis labs daily
   - Continue Procrit, Fe++ po; increased folate 1mg to 4mg Qday
   .
   #Coagulopathy: Likely component of shock liver, subacute DIC, and HIT.
   Platelets gradually decreasing over the course of the hospital stay.
   INR increasing. Found to be HIT+ [**4-18**]. Per heme, will check serotonin
   release assay for confirmation and monitor INR/PTT.
   - F/U serotonin release assay. F/U daily coags.
   - If coags normalize (PTT <60), will consider starting Argatroban
   .
   #Transaminitis: Likely due to shock liver in setting of distributive
   picture with decreased EF. RUQ u/s shows known CBD dialation, s/p
   chole. Stable.
   .
   #Dysphonia
 due to cuffed 8.0 trach
   - Will hold off changing to smaller cuff until resp status improves
   - ENT consult as needed as outpatient, confirmed with ENT and IP on
   [**2167-4-7**]. Got PMV on [**4-6**].
   .
   #Mental Status: Alert and oriented x 3, clear mentation x48 hours.
   Frustrated with long ICU stay and illness. [**Month (only) 60**] also be delirious at
   moments.
   - Frequent reorientation; maintain sleep-wake cycle.
   - Hold Ativan. Use  Zyprexa PRN for agitation.
   .
   CV: Stable. CK elevated in the setting of hypovolemia/shock. No
   ischemic EKG changes. .
   CAD: CABG [**2146**] with multiple PCI.  Continue ASA, statin, re-start BB
   when pressures stable.
   PUMP: EF 29%.  Off of pressors, rpt echo EF 25%
   RHYTHM: CHB s/p DDD PCM,ICD in [**2160**]. Not on Warfarin.
   -          Maintain on telemetry
   -          Maintain Hct >21, ideally >25, but issues with transfusing,
   see above.
   -          Continue midodrine
   .
   FEN
 holding tube feeds at this time. Replete lytes PRN. Attempt PICC
   placement today for ?TPN.
   PPx
d Hep SQ for suspicion of HIT (Heme recs to follow), placed on
   pneumoboots, H2 qday
   Code - full
   Access
 HD line, A line (placed [**2167-4-16**]). Attempt PICC today.
   Dispo
 MICU for now

The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease, presenting with septic shock and multiorgan failure secondary to community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) complicated by ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient is currently on continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH) and has Clostridium difficile colitis, for which he is receiving oral vancomycin and intravenous metronidazole. He also has a fungal upper abdominal abscess and is being treated with fluconazole.

The patient's medical complications include:
1. Leukocytosis/fever: The patient is afebrile for the past 48 hours, but his lactate levels are fluctuating. A CT scan of the torso shows a fluid/air collection in the duodenum adjacent to the pancreas, which was drained with percutaneous irrigation on [4-17]. Gram stain of the drainage shows budding yeast, indicating a fungal infection. Fluconazole was added on [4-16] for fungal coverage. The beta-glucan test was canceled due to a hemolyzed sample.
2. Shock/hypotension: The patient initially presented with hypotension in the setting of septic shock. He received early goal-directed therapy, and his Apache IV score was 114. The sources of shock are likely pneumonia, Clostridium difficile infection, and intra-abdominal abscess. Levophed requirement is

The patient is a 64-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a history of chronic heart failure, chronic renal failure, sepsis with organ dysfunction, and multiple other comorbidities. The patient's current condition includes altered tissue perfusion, coagulopathy, C. difficile infection, systolic chronic heart failure, hemolytic anemia, impaired skin integrity, hypotension, anxiety, impaired aerobic capacity/endurance, balance, muscle performance, ventilation, altered mental status, malnutrition, hyperglycemia, severe sepsis with organ dysfunction, chronic renal failure, and acute respiratory distress syndrome.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) due to prolonged immobilization and central venous catheters.
2. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to prolonged mechanical ventilation.
3. Nosocomial infections such as catheter-related bloodstream infections (CRBSI) and pressure ulcers.
4. Further deterioration of renal function leading to acute kidney injury (AKI).
5. Development of multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS) due to ongoing sepsis and underlying comorbidities.
6. Progression of heart failure leading to cardiogenic shock.
7. Complications related to C. difficile infection, including severe colitis and toxic megacolon.
8. Hypotension and hemodynamic instability due to sepsis and chronic heart failure.
9. Impaired wound healing and

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease, presenting with septic shock and multiorgan failure due to CAP (pneumonia) complicated by VAP (ventilator-associated pneumonia). The patient also has C. diff colitis and an upper abdominal fungal abscess. 

The patient's current medical issues include:

1. Shock/Hypotension: The patient was initially hypotensive in the setting of septic shock. He received early goal-directed therapy, and his Apache IV score was 114. PNA, C. diff, and intra-abdominal abscess are likely sources. Levophed requirement decreased overnight. Shock may be both septic and cardiogenic (due to ischemic heart disease with EF 20-30%). The patient is currently on levophed and midodrine.

2. Respiratory Failure/ARDS: The patient has ARDS secondary to PNA. He is intubated and on assist control ventilation with a 28 liter bag. Pressure support ventilation trials are being attempted as tolerated.

3. Leukocytosis/Fever: The patient has been afebrile for 72 hours, but his lactate levels are fluctuating between 2-3. A CT scan showed a fluid/air collection in the duodenum adjacent to the pancreas, which was drained with IR on 4/17. Gram stain showed budding yeast, and flu

He is currently on CVVH, experiencing oliguric acute on chronic ARF/uremia, anemia of chronic disease, subacute DIC, and HIT. The patient's condition is complex, involving various organ systems and requiring multiple interventions.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Shock/Hypotension: The patient initially presented with septic shock, which may be both septic and cardiogenic in nature. He requires continuous monitoring and management of his blood pressure, possibly with the use of inotropes and diuretics.

2. Respiratory Failure/ARDS: The patient has ARDS secondary to pneumonia, for which he has been intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation. Pressure support ventilation trials should be continued as tolerated, considering ongoing diuresis.

3. Leukocytosis/Fever: Although the patient has been afebrile for the past 48 hours, his lactate levels are fluctuating. Close monitoring is required, and further investigation into the source of infection is necessary.

4. Oliguric, Acute on Chronic ARF/Uremia: The patient's renal function is compromised due to acute tubular necrosis. He is currently on CVVH and should continue gentle diuresis while closely monitoring blood

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with multiple comorbidities including chronic heart failure, chronic renal failure, and diabetes. He was admitted to the ICU with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and septic shock. The patient's abdominal abscess has grown and is sensitive to Serratia and yeast. He has been switched to cefepime and further identification of the yeast is pending. The patient continues to be NPO per surgery. Stool guaiac is negative, and daily hemolysis labs are being followed per Heme. Mini BAL shows no PMNs or organisms. A PICC line was started at 03:00 PM on [**2167-4-20**]. The patient has several allergies including cholestyramine, niacin, hepatic toxicity, iodine, rash, ciprofloxacin, muscle weakness, and heparin agents due to HIT. The patient's last doses of antibiotics were vancomycin at [**2167-4-20**] 12:06 AM, meropenem at [**2167-4-20**] 09:02 PM, fluconazole at [**2167-4-21**] 12:09 AM, cefepime at [**2167-4-21**] 01:49 AM, and metronidazole at [**2167-4-21**] 04:16 AM. The patient is currently on norepinephrine at 0.06 mcg/kg/min and morphine sulfate at [**2167-4-21**] 03:03 AM. The patient's review of systems is unchanged from admission except for the noted below. The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.3 C (97.3 F), heart rate of 87 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 91/37-104/68 mmHg, respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient's heart rhythm is ventricular-paced. The patient's fluid balance shows a total in of 6,695 mL and out of 6,972 mL, resulting in a negative balance of 277 mL. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a set tidal volume of 500 mL, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and peak inspiratory pressure of 21 cmH2O. The patient's arterial blood gas results are pending. The patient's lab results show leukocytosis with a WBC count of 14.9 K/uL, elevated hemoglobin of 7.9 g/dL, elevated creatinine of 1.05 mg/dL, and low potassium of 3.8 mEq/L. The patient's PT/INR is elevated at 20.9/2.0, and his CK/CKMB/troponin

   Assessment and Plan
   81M with ischemic heart dz EF 30%, p/w septic shock and multiorgan
   failure from CAP PNA complicated by VAP, currently on CVVH w/ ongoing
   pressor requirement. Current infectious issues include C. diff colitis
   and intra-abd fungal/GNR abscess.
   .
   #. Shock/Hypotension:   Was initially hypotensive in setting of septic
   shock.  Had Early Goal Directed Therapy with Apache IV score of 114.
   PNA, C. diff, intra-abdominal abscess are likely sources. Levophed
   requirement decreased overnight from 0.07->0.05. Shock may be both
   septic and cardiogenic (pt has ischemic heart disease with EF 20-30%,
   MvO2 = 52% on [**4-18**]). Currently on levophed and midodrine. Has been
   difficult to wean levophed in setting of CVVH. Also unsure if BP
   measurements are accurate as have not been able to obtain invasive
   monitoring and currently only [**Location (un) 308**] off right forearm BP cuff. Mental
   status appears more clear than what would be expected for SBPs in the
   80s.
   - Check thigh/calf pressures today. If these SBP > 110s, will rapidly
   wean levophed.
   - Recheck MvO2 today. If low, consider starting dobutamine vs.
   vasopressin.
   - On CVVH; continuing gentle diuresis of 50cc neg/hr since pt is volume
   overloaded (however limited by low BP).
   - Wean levophed as tolerated.
   - Continue midodrine 10mg TID
   .
   #. Resp failure/ ARDS: ARDS secondary to PNA. Patient trached on [**4-1**].
   On Vent, Assist Control. 26L positive for length of stay at highest
   point.
   - Pressure support ventilation trials as tolerated. [**Month (only) 60**] tolerate it
   better with continued diuresis.
   .
   #.Leukocytosis/fever
 Pt afebrile x 4days. Lactate fluctuating, [**3-17**]
   range. Completed 11 days of Meropenem for pansensitive Serratia and
   Klebsiella HAP. CT torso showed a fluid/air collection in duodenum, adj
   to pancreas, so it was drained with IR on [**4-17**] with pigtail placement,
   and gram stain shows budding yeast, pan-sensitive Serratia.
   Galactomannin negative; beta-glucan was cancelled due to hemolyzed
   sample.  Started Fluconazole [**4-16**] and [**Last Name (un) **] [**4-19**] for intra-abdominal
   abscess.
   - Added Cefepime and d/c
d Meropenem for pan-sensitive serratia on [**4-20**]
   (Day 1 Cefepime [**2167-4-20**])
   - On PO vanc  and IV flagyl for c. diff. Treat 14 day course for C.
   diff when cefepime is d/c
d again. Pt may ultimately require a taper to
   prevent recurrence.
   - On Fluconazole (Day 6) for fungal abscess per ID recs.
   - F/U speciation of yeast and adjust anti-fungals as needed.
   - f/u ID recs
   - f/u surgery recs for further management upper abd abcess
 recommend
   advancing Gtube to G-J for post-abcess feeds.
   - f/u IR recs for drain flushes and need for further abd imaging.
   .
   #. Oliguric, acute on chronic ARF/Uremia: Baseline Cr 2.3.  Patient in
   ARF from acute tubular necrosis in setting of hypotension.  Pt on CVVH
   at this time. Will continue on CVVH until off pressors.
   - Renal following, appreciate recs
   - On Neutra-phos per Renal
   - Continue EPO
   .
   #Anemia
 Patient has anemia of chronic disease, limited benefit from
   iron supp, but little harm to give it. Folate nl, B12 high, evidence of
   ongoing hemolysis b/c has persistently low hapto, high LDH, high D
   Bili. Stool guaiac negative. Appropriate reticulocytosis. Pt tested
   super Coombs positive (DAT) but on repeat testing on [**4-17**] Coombs neg.
   Should still only transfuse in emergency settings of active ischemia.
   Patient likely has subacute DIC. Per Heme, blood bank has 1 U frozen
   for this patient.
   - Transfused 1U [**4-18**] with appropriate Hct bump from 19->25.
   - appreciate heme recs: check hemolysis labs daily, guaiac stool (neg
   thus far); f/u further recs.
   - Continue Procrit, Fe++ po; folate 4mg Qday
   .
   #Coagulopathy: Likely component of shock liver, subacute DIC, and HIT.
   Platelets gradually decreasing over the course of the hospital stay.
   INR increasing. Found to be HIT+ [**4-18**]. Per heme, will check serotonin
   release assay for confirmation and monitor INR/PTT. **Pt needs separate
   order for platelet count daily.
   - F/U serotonin release assay. F/U daily coags.
   - Per Heme: If coags normalize (PTT <60), consider starting Argatroban.
   PTT is < 60, but risks for bleeding in this pt if on Argatroban are
   substantial, and will thus wait for SRA result. Appreciate further heme
   recs.
   .
   #Transaminitis: Likely due to shock liver in setting of distributive
   picture with decreased EF. RUQ u/s shows known CBD dialation, s/p
   chole. Stable.
   .
   #Dysphonia
 due to cuffed 8.0 trach
   - Will hold off changing to smaller cuff until resp status improves
   - ENT consult as needed as outpatient, confirmed with ENT and IP on
   [**2167-4-7**]. Got PMV on [**4-6**].
   .
   #Mental Status: Alert and oriented x 3, clear mentation for at least 4
   days. Frustrated with long ICU stay and illness. [**Month (only) 60**] also be delirious
   at moments.
   - Frequent reorientation; maintain sleep-wake cycle.
   - Hold Ativan. Use  Zyprexa PRN for agitation.
   .
   #CV: Stable. CK elevated in the setting of hypovolemia/shock. No
   ischemic EKG changes. .
   CAD: CABG [**2146**] with multiple PCI.  Continue ASA, statin, re-start BB
   when pressures stable.
   PUMP: EF 29%.  Off of pressors, rpt echo EF 25%
   RHYTHM: CHB s/p DDD PCM,ICD in [**2160**]. Not on Warfarin.
   - Maintain on telemetry
   - Maintain Hct >21, ideally >25, but issues with transfusing, see
   above. Last transfusion 1U PRBCs [**4-18**].
   - Continue midodrine
   .
   #Tremor: Pt has new resting and action tremor in bilateral hands.
   Differential includes side effect of levophed, neuropathy from chronic
   illness, and ongoing hypocalcemia. Given multiple other issues at this
   time, would not be worthwhile to work up tremor with neurology. Will
   continue to monitor and initiate workup if tremor persists after more
   acute issues resolve.
   .
   FEN
 Holding TFs per surgery. Replete lytes PRN. Place G-J w/ IR today
   for post-abscess feeds.
   PPx
 Pboots, PPI qday. No heparin (HIT+).
   Code - full
   Access
 HD line, PICC.
   Dispo
 MICU for now

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease and ejection fraction of 30% who was admitted to the ICU for septic shock and multiorgan failure secondary to community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) complicated by ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient is currently on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) with ongoing pressor requirement. He has been diagnosed with C. diff colitis and intra-abdominal fungal/gamma-neg. abscess. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Shock/Hypotension: The patient was initially hypotensive in the setting of septic shock. There is a concern for both septic and cardiogenic shock due to the patient's ischemic heart disease with an ejection fraction of 20-30%. The patient is currently on levophed and midodrine, and it has been difficult to wean off levophed due to CVVH. The mental status appears more clear than expected for the blood pressure readings in the 80s. 
- Check thigh/calf pressures today. If these SBP > 110s, will rapidly wean levophed.
- Recheck MvO2 today. If low, consider starting dobutamine vs. vasopressin.
- Continue CVVH and gentle diuresis of 50cc neg/hr since pt is volume overloaded.
- Wean lev

The patient is a 81-year-old male with ischemic heart disease and a baseline ejection fraction of 30% who presented with septic shock and multiorgan failure secondary to community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) complicated by ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient has been diagnosed with several medical complications including:

1. Shock/Hypotension: The patient was initially hypotensive due to septic shock, which is likely caused by the pneumonia, intra-abdominal abscess, and possibly cardiogenic factors due to his ischemic heart disease. He is currently on norepinephrine and midodrine to maintain blood pressure.

2. Respiratory failure/ARDS: The patient developed acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) secondary to the CAP. He is intubated and on mechanical ventilation.

3. Leukocytosis/Fever: The patient had leukocytosis and fever, which is consistent with an ongoing infection. His temperature has been afebrile for the past 72 hours.

4. Oliguric, acute on chronic ARF/Uremia: The patient has acute kidney injury (AKI) on top of chronic kidney disease (CKD). His baseline creatinine was 2.3, and he is currently on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH).

5. Anemia: The patient has anemia of chronic disease with evidence of ongoing hemolysis. He should only be transfused

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease, who presented with septic shock and multiorgan failure from CAP PNA complicated by VAP. He is currently on CVVH with ongoing pressor requirement. The patient has several ongoing medical issues:

1. Shock/Hypotension: The patient was initially hypotensive in the setting of septic shock. He has been receiving early goal-directed therapy, but his blood pressure measurements may not be accurate due to the absence of invasive monitoring. Weaning of levophed and consideration of starting dobutamine or vasopressin should be considered.

2. Resp failure/ARDS: The patient has ARDS secondary to PNA. He is intubated and on assist control ventilation. Pressure support ventilation trials should be continued as tolerated.

3. Leukocytosis/Fever: The patient was previously febrile but is now afebrile for four days. Lactate levels have been fluctuating. He has completed 11 days of meropenem for pansensitive Serratia and Klebsiella HAP. A CT scan showed a fluid/air collection in the duodenum adjacent to the pancreas, which was drained with IR on [date]. The gram stain of the drainage showed budding yeast, pan-sensitive Serratia. Fluconazole and cefepime were started, and the patient is currently on PO vancomycin and IV flagyl for C. diff.

4. Oliguric, acute on chronic ARF/Uremia: The patient has acute tubular necrosis and is on CVVH. Renal function should continue to be closely monitored.

5. Anemia: The patient has anemia of chronic disease, but there is limited benefit from iron supplementation. However, it is safe to give it. Folate levels are normal, B12 levels are high, and there is evidence of ongoing hemolysis. The patient tested positive for super Coombs but was negative on repeat testing. Only transfuse in emergency settings of active ischemia.

6. Coagulopathy: The patient likely has subacute DIC and HIT. Platelets are gradually decreasing, and INR is increasing. The patient should have daily platelet counts, and further heme recommendations should be followed.

7. Transaminitis: This is likely due to shock liver in the setting of distributive picture with decreased EF. RUQ ultrasound shows known CBD dilation, which was stable after cholecystectomy.

8. Dysphonia: This is due to the cuffed tracheostomy tube. It is important to hold off changing to a smaller cuff until respiratory status improves.

9. Mental Status: The patient is alert and oriented x3, with clear mentation for at least four days. He may experience delirium at moments

   at this time. Will continue on CVVH until off pressors.
   - Renal following, appreciate recs
   - On Neutra-phos per Renal
   - Continue EPO
   .
   #Anemia
 Patient has anemia of chronic disease, limited benefit from
   iron supp, but little harm to give it. Folate nl, B12 high, evidence of
   ongoing hemolysis b/c has persistently low hapto, high LDH, high D
   Bili. Stool guaiac negative. Appropriate reticulocytosis. Pt tested
   super Coombs positive (DAT) but on repeat testing on [**4-17**] Coombs neg.
   Should still only transfuse in emergency settings of active ischemia.
   Patient likely has subacute DIC. Per Heme, blood bank has 1 U frozen
   for this patient.
   - Transfused 1U [**4-18**] with appropriate Hct bump from 19->25.
   - appreciate heme recs: check hemolysis labs daily, guaiac stool (neg
   thus far); f/u further recs.
   - Continue Procrit, Fe++ po; folate 4mg Qday
   - F/U Super Coombs test from Blood Bank.
   .
   #Coagulopathy: Likely component of shock liver, subacute DIC, and HIT.
   Platelets gradually decreasing over the course of the hospital stay.
   Found to be HIT+ [**4-18**]. Per heme, will check serotonin release assay for
   confirmation and monitor INR/PTT. **Pt needs separate order for
   platelet count daily.
   - F/U serotonin release assay. F/U daily coags.
   - Per Heme: If coags normalize (PTT <60), consider starting Argatroban.
   PTT is < 60, but risks for bleeding in this pt if on Argatroban are
   substantial, and will thus wait for SRA result. Appreciate further heme
   recs.
   .
   #Transaminitis: Likely due to shock liver in setting of distributive
   picture with decreased EF. RUQ u/s shows known CBD dialation, s/p
   chole. Stable.
   .
   #Dysphonia
 due to cuffed 8.0 trach
   - Will hold off changing to smaller cuff until resp status improves
   - ENT consult as needed as outpatient, confirmed with ENT and IP on
   [**2167-4-7**]. Got PMV on [**4-6**].
   .
   #Mental Status: Alert and oriented x 3, clear mentation for at least 4
   days. Frustrated with long ICU stay and illness. [**Month (only) 60**] also be delirious
   at moments.
   - Frequent reorientation; maintain sleep-wake cycle.
   - Hold Ativan. Use  Zyprexa PRN for agitation.
   .
   #CV: Stable. CK elevated in the setting of hypovolemia/shock. No
   ischemic EKG changes. .
   CAD: CABG [**2146**] with multiple PCI.  Continue ASA, statin, re-start BB
   when pressures stable.
   PUMP: EF 29%.  Off of pressors, rpt echo EF 25%
   RHYTHM: CHB s/p DDD PCM,ICD in [**2160**]. Not on Warfarin.
   - Maintain on telemetry
   - Maintain Hct >21, ideally >25, but issues with transfusing, see
   above. Last transfusion 1U PRBCs [**4-18**].
   - Continue midodrine
   .
   #Tremor: Pt has new resting and action tremor in bilateral hands.
   Differential includes side effect of levophed, neuropathy from chronic
   illness, and ongoing hypocalcemia. Given multiple other issues at this
   time, would not be worthwhile to work up tremor with neurology. Will
   continue to monitor and initiate workup if tremor persists after more
   acute issues resolve.
   .

The patient has a history of ischemic heart disease with an ejection fraction of 30%, and there is also a cardiogenic component to the shock. The patient has been treated for various conditions including C. difficile colitis, intra-abdominal fungal/Gram-negative bacterial abscess, and multiorgan failure.

The patient is currently on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) with ongoing pressor requirement. They have been hypotensive and required early goal-directed therapy. The patient's respiratory status is complicated by ARDS secondary to pneumonia, and they have been on mechanical ventilation with pressure support trials as tolerated.

The patient has leukocytosis and fever, and there is a concern for ongoing infection. They have been treated with multiple antibiotics, including cefepime, vancomycin, and fluconazole. The patient also has anemia of chronic disease, ongoing hemolysis, and a positive Super Coombs test initially, which later turned negative. They have been transfused with packed red blood cells.

The patient has a coagulopathy likely due to shock liver, subacute disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). They have been found to be HIT positive, and their platelet count has been decreasing over time.

The patient also has transaminitis likely due to shock liver, dysphonia

The patient is a [age]-year-old male admitted to the ICU with septic shock and ventilator-associated pneumonia. The patient has multiple comorbidities including chronic systolic heart failure, chronic renal failure, hemolytic anemia, and anxiety. The patient's current condition is unstable with altered mental status, impaired balance, muscle performance, and ventilation. The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation and has been on pressors for hemodynamic support. The patient's blood cultures have shown an increase in lactate levels, indicating ongoing tissue perfusion abnormalities.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Sepsis: The patient's presentation of septic shock indicates a systemic infection that may lead to organ dysfunction.
2. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient has been on mechanical ventilation for an extended period, increasing the risk of developing pneumonia.

4. Renal failure: The patient's chronic renal failure may worsen due to decreased renal perfusion in the setting of sepsis.
5. Chronic systolic heart failure: The patient's pre-existing heart condition can be exacerbated by sepsis and fluid shifts.
6. Hemolytic anemia: The patient's anemia may progress if the underlying cause is not addressed.
7. Malnutrition: Prolonged ICU stay and impaired

   81M with ischemic heart dz EF 30%, p/w septic shock and multiorgan
   failure from CAP PNA complicated by VAP, currently on CVVH w/ ongoing
   pressor requirement. Current infectious issues include C. diff colitis

   #. Hypotension:   Was initially hypotensive in setting of septic
   shock.  Had Early Goal Directed Therapy with Apache IV score of 114.
   PNA, C. diff, intra-abdominal abscess are likely sources. [**Month (only) 60**] also have
   cardiogenic component to shock as pt has ischemic heart disease with EF
   20-30%, MvO2 = 52% on [**4-18**], PaO2 26-27 on [**4-21**].  Had A-line pulled on
   [**4-19**] and are unable to obtain central pressure monitoring; unsure if
   cuff BP measurements are accurate. Mentating well with SBPs in 80s.
   Levophed and midodrine weaned overnight; no longer requiring pressors.
   Able to remove ___ fluid with CVVH yesterday. Lactate elevated at 5.9
   this morning.
   - On CVVH; continuing gentle diuresis of 50cc neg/hr since pt is volume
   overloaded (however limited by low BP).
   - Continue to monitor pressure with goal MAP 50-55.
   .
   #. Resp failure/ ARDS: ARDS secondary to PNA. Patient trached on [**4-1**].
   On Vent, Assist Control. Tolerated PS trials yesterday but then
   required MMV for apnea.
   - Continue Pressure Support trials as tolerated.
   .
   #.Leukocytosis/fever
 Pt afebrile x 5days. Lactate doubled this AM to
   5.9, repeat BC sent. Completed 11 days of Meropenem for pansensitive
   Serratia and Klebsiella HAP. Abd abscess growing budding yeast,
   pan-[**Last Name (un) **] Serratia, drained w/ IR on [**4-17**], pigtail in place.
   Galactomannin negative; beta-glucan was cancelled due to hemolyzed
   sample.  Started Fluconazole [**4-16**] and [**Last Name (un) **] [**4-19**] for intra-abdominal
   abscess.
   - Continue Cefepime (Day 1 Cefepime [**2167-4-20**])
   - On PO vanc  and IV flagyl for c. diff. Treat 14 day course for C.
   diff when cefepime is d/c
d again. Pt may ultimately require a taper to
   prevent recurrence.
   - Continue Fluconazole (Day 7) for fungal abscess.
   - F/U speciation of yeast and adjust anti-fungals as needed.
   - f/u ID recs
   - Had G-J tube placed w/ IR [**4-21**] for post-abscess tube feeds
   .

   Bili. Stool guaiac negative. Appropriate reticulocytosis. Pt tested
   super Coombs positive (DAT) but on repeat testing on [**4-17**] Coombs neg.
   Should still only transfuse in emergency settings of active ischemia.

   for this patient.

   - appreciate heme recs: check hemolysis labs daily, guaiac stool (neg
   thus far); f/u further recs.
   - Continue Procrit, Fe++ po; folate 4mg Qday
   - F/U Super Coombs test from Blood Bank.
   .
   #Coagulopathy: Likely component of shock liver, subacute DIC, and HIT.
   Platelets gradually decreasing over the course of the hospital stay.
   Found to be HIT+ [**4-18**]. Per heme, will check serotonin release assay for
   confirmation and monitor INR/PTT. **Pt needs separate order for

   PTT is < 60, but risks for bleeding in this pt if on Argatroban are
   substantial, and will thus wait for SRA result. Appreciate further heme
   recs.
   .
   #Transaminitis: Likely due to shock liver in setting of distributive
   picture with decreased EF. RUQ u/s shows known CBD dialation, s/p
   chole. Stable.
   .
   #Dysphonia
 due to cuffed 8.0 trach
   - Will hold off changing to smaller cuff until resp status improves
   - ENT consult as needed as outpatient, confirmed with ENT and IP on
   [**2167-4-7**]. Got PMV on [**4-6**].
   .
   #Mental Status: Alert and oriented x 3, clear mentation for at least 4
   days. Frustrated with long ICU stay and illness. [**Month (only) 60**] also be delirious
   at moments.
   - Frequent reorientation; maintain sleep-wake cycle.
   - Hold Ativan. Use  Zyprexa PRN for agitation.
   .
   #CV: Stable. CK elevated in the setting of hypovolemia/shock. No
   ischemic EKG changes. .
   CAD: CABG [**2146**] with multiple PCI.  Continue ASA, statin, re-start BB
   when pressures stable.
   PUMP: EF 29%.  Off of pressors, rpt echo EF 25%
   RHYTHM: CHB s/p DDD PCM,ICD in [**2160**]. Not on Warfarin.
   - Maintain on telemetry
   - Maintain Hct >21, ideally >25, but issues with transfusing, see
   above. Last transfusion 1U PRBCs [**4-18**].
   - Continue midodrine
   .
   #Tremor: Pt has new resting and action tremor in bilateral hands.
   Differential includes side effect of levophed, neuropathy from chronic
   illness, and ongoing hypocalcemia. Given multiple other issues at this
   time, would not be worthwhile to work up tremor with neurology. Will
   continue to monitor and initiate workup if tremor persists after more
   acute issues resolve.
   .
   FEN
 Holding TFs per surgery. Replete lytes PRN. Place G-J w/ IR today
   for post-abscess feeds.

 Pboots, PPI qday. No heparin (HIT+).

The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease and ejection fraction of 30% who presented with septic shock and multiorgan failure secondary to community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) complicated by ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). He has been in the ICU for over a month and has developed various complications including C. difficile colitis, intra-abdominal fungal and gram-negative bacterial abscess, acute kidney injury, anemia, coagulopathy, and transaminitis. The patient is currently on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH), receiving multiple antibiotics, antifungals, and supportive care.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypotension: The patient's initial hypotension in the setting of septic shock may be due to several factors including pneumonia, cardiogenic component from ischemic heart disease, and possibly distributive shock. It is important to monitor blood pressure closely and continue with gentle diuresis as tolerated.
2. Respiratory failure/ARDS: The patient has ARDS secondary to PNA and requires mechanical ventilation. Pressure support trials should be continued as tolerated to wean off ventilatory support.
3. Leukocytosis/fever: Although the patient has been afebrile for five days, the recent increase in lactate levels suggests ongoing infection. Repeat blood cultures should be sent, and appropriate antimicrobial therapy should be continued.

3. Leukocytosis/fever: Although the patient has been afebrile for five days, the lactate level has doubled, and a repeat blood culture has been sent. It is important to continue monitoring for signs of infection and adjusting the antibiotic regimen accordingly.

TEXT:
Chief Complaint: Septic shock, Multi-Organ Dysfunction,
   Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia
   24 Hour Events:
   *Hypotension:
   - Added back levophed for SBPs in 60s with elevated lactate, poor
   mental status.
   - Trial dobutamine for goal MAP 55, SBP 90 --> not much benefit; d/c'd
   and added vasopressin instead.
   - Was doing well on vasopressin only (levophed turned off), but BP
   decreased, thus levophed was re-added, initially at 0.3mcg/kg. Pt
   mentating fine.
   - ID Recs -> continue Fluc until yeast speciation returns. If
   deteriorates, switch to micafungin (has been switched; also gave
   one-time dose of IV vancomycin)
   - Per Surgery -> will need interval CTAbd in 2 wks.
   - CT Abd obtained to check for interval change in the abscess
   (Radiology not willing to do IV contrast due to no PIV)
 Prelim Read:
   Large b/l pleural effusions w/ RLL consolidation and air bronchograms
   suspic for PNA. Decreased size of abd fluid collection. Persistent
   anasarca.
   - Transfused 1U PRBCs overnight (started at midnight). ?leak during
   transfusion, may only have received
 unit.
   - Renal recs -> give Albumin w/ CVVH to keep BP stable if warranted
   - Left arm swellling noted: U/S done, prelim: No DVT LUE
   Asymm waveforms in subsclavian vein with less variability in left - of
   unknown clinical significance
   Allergies:

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old male with a chief complaint of septic shock, multi-organ dysfunction, and ventilator-associated pneumonia. The patient has been experiencing hypotension and requires multiple vasopressors for blood pressure control. There is evidence of large bilateral pleural effusions with right lower lobe consolidation, suggesting pneumonia. The patient also has anasarca and decreased size of abdominal fluid collection. Renal recommendations include giving albumin with continuous veno-venous hemodialfiltration (CVVH) to maintain blood pressure stability. Additionally, the patient has a left arm swelling, but an ultrasound preliminary report indicates no deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Allergies include cholestyramine, niacin, iodine, ciprofloxacin, heparin agents, and muscle weakness. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Septic Shock: The patient's current condition of septic shock can lead to complications such as organ dysfunction, hypotension, and respiratory distress.
2. Multi-Organ Dysfunction Syndrome: Due to sepsis and septic shock, the patient may develop multi-organ dysfunction syndrome, which can affect various organs including the kidneys, liver, heart, and lungs.
3. Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia: The presence of pneumonia in a patient on mechanical ventilation increases the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia, which can worsen respiratory status and lead to further complications.
4. Renal Failure

   and added vasopressin instead.

   decreased, thus levophed was re-added, initially at 0.3mcg/kg. Pt

   Assessment and Plan
   81M with ischemic heart dz EF 30%, p/w septic shock and multiorgan
   failure from CAP PNA complicated by VAP, currently on CVVH w/ ongoing
   pressor requirement. Current infectious issues include C. diff colitis
   and intra-abd fungal/GNR abscess.
   .
   #. Shock/Hypotension:   Was initially hypotensive in setting of septic
   shock.  Had Early Goal Directed Therapy with Apache IV score of 114.
   PNA, C. diff, intra-abdominal abscess are likely sources for sepsis.
   [**Month (only) 60**] also have cardiogenic component to shock as pt has ischemic heart
   disease with EF 20-30%, MvO2 = 52% on [**4-18**], PaO2 26-27 on [**4-21**].  Had
   A-line pulled on [**4-19**] and are unable to obtain central pressure
   monitoring; Has thigh cuff now but insure if cuff BP measurements are
   accurate. Levophed and midodrine weaned overnight and 1.5L removed w/
   CVVH yesterday, however lactate rose to 5.9 w/ decreasing mental
   status. Restarted levophed at 0.2mcg/kg this AM for SBPs in 60s.
   - Trial dobutamine for probable cardiogenic component to ongoing
   hypotension.
   - Will hold CVVH during dobutamine trial and plan to restart tonight.
   - Continue to monitor pressure with goal MAP 55, SPB 90.
   .
   #. Resp failure/ ARDS: ARDS secondary to PNA. Patient trached on [**4-1**].
   On Vent, Assist Control. Tolerated PS trials yesterday but then
   required MMV for apnea and Assist Control after midnight.
   - Continue Pressure Support trials as tolerated.
   .
   #.Leukocytosis/fever
 Pt afebrile x 5days. Lactate doubled this AM to
   5.9, repeat BC sent. Completed 11 days of Meropenem for pansensitive
   Serratia and Klebsiella HAP. Abd abscess growing budding yeast,
   pan-[**Last Name (un) **] Serratia, drained w/ IR on [**4-17**], pigtail in place.
   Galactomannin negative; beta-glucan was cancelled due to hemolyzed
   sample.  Started Fluconazole [**4-16**] and [**Last Name (un) **] [**4-19**] for intra-abdominal
   abscess.
   - Continue Cefepime (Day 1 Cefepime [**2167-4-20**])
   - On PO vanc  and IV flagyl for c. diff. Treat 14 day course for C.
   diff when cefepime is d/c
d again. Pt may ultimately require a taper to
   prevent recurrence.
   - Continue Fluconazole (Day 7) for fungal abscess.
   - F/U speciation of yeast and adjust anti-fungals as needed.
   - f/u ID recs
   - Had G-J tube placed w/ IR [**4-21**] for post-abscess tube feeds
   - F/U repeat Blood Cx
   .
   #. Oliguric, acute on chronic ARF/Uremia: Baseline Cr 2.3.  Patient in
   ARF from acute tubular necrosis in setting of hypotension.  Pt on CVVH
   at this time, holding temporarily during dobutamine trial. Will
   continue on CVVH until off pressors.
   - Renal following, appreciate recs
   - On Neutra-phos per Renal
   - Continue EPO
   .
   #Anemia
 Patient has anemia of chronic disease, limited benefit from
   iron supp, but little harm to give it. Folate nl, B12 high, evidence of
   ongoing hemolysis b/c has persistently low hapto, high LDH, high D
   Bili. Stool guaiac negative. Appropriate reticulocytosis. Pt tested
   super Coombs positive (DAT) but on repeat testing on [**4-17**] Coombs neg.
   Will not repeat Super Coombs per Heme. Should still only transfuse in
   emergency settings of active ischemia. Patient likely has subacute DIC.
   Per Heme, blood bank has 2 U frozen for this patient.
   - Transfused 1U [**4-18**] with appropriate Hct bump from 19->25, but Hct down
   again today to 22.
   - appreciate heme recs: check hemolysis labs daily, guaiac stool (neg
   thus far); f/u further recs.
   - Continue Procrit, Fe++ po; folate 4mg Qday
   - Transfused 1U today and check post-transfusion Hct.
   .
   #Coagulopathy: Likely component of shock liver, subacute DIC, and HIT.
   Platelets gradually decreasing over the course of the hospital stay.
   Found to be HIT+ [**4-18**]. Per heme, will check serotonin release assay for
   confirmation and monitor INR/PTT. **Pt needs separate order for
   platelet count daily.
   - F/U serotonin release assay. F/U daily coags.
   - Per Heme: If coags normalize (PTT <60), consider starting Argatroban.
   PTT is < 60, but risks for bleeding in this pt if on Argatroban are
   substantial, and will thus wait for SRA result. Appreciate further heme
   recs.
   .
   #Transaminitis: Likely due to shock liver in setting of distributive
   picture with decreased EF. RUQ u/s shows known CBD dialation, s/p
   chole. Stable.
   .
   #Dysphonia
 due to cuffed 8.0 trach
   - Will hold off changing to smaller cuff until resp status improves
   - ENT consult as needed as outpatient, confirmed with ENT and IP on
   [**2167-4-7**]. Got PMV on [**4-6**].
   .
   #Mental Status: Alert and oriented x 3, clear mentation for past 4
   days, unless more somnolent this AM off pressors. Frustrated with long
   ICU stay and illness. Will reassess mental status when back on pressors
   later today.
   - Frequent reorientation; maintain sleep-wake cycle.
   - Hold Ativan. Use  Zyprexa PRN for agitation.
   .
   #CV: Stable. CK elevated in the setting of hypovolemia/shock. No
   ischemic EKG changes. .
   CAD: CABG [**2146**] with multiple PCI.  Continue ASA, statin, re-start BB
   when pressures stable.
   PUMP: EF 29%.  Off of pressors, rpt echo EF 25%
   RHYTHM: CHB s/p DDD PCM,ICD in [**2160**]. Not on Warfarin.
   - Maintain on telemetry
   - Maintain Hct >21, ideally >25, but issues with transfusing, see
   above.
   - Continue midodrine/dobutamine.
   .
   #Tremor: Pt has new resting and action tremor in bilateral hands.
   Differential includes side effect of levophed, neuropathy from chronic
   illness, and ongoing hypocalcemia. Given multiple other issues at this
   time, would not be worthwhile to work up tremor with neurology. Will
   continue to monitor and initiate workup if tremor persists after more
   acute issues resolve.
   .
   FEN
Tube feeds @ 30cc/hr via G-J and advance as tolerated. Replete
   lytes PRN.
   PPx
 Pboots, PPI qday. No heparin (HIT+).
   Code - full
   Access
 HD line, PICC.
   Dispo
 MICU for now

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease, presenting with septic shock, multi-organ dysfunction, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation and has been in the ICU for several weeks. He has developed complications such as acute kidney injury (AKI), anemia, coagulopathy, and dysphonia. The patient's condition remains unstable, and he requires ongoing pressor support.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Shock/Hypotension: The patient is experiencing ongoing hypotension despite receiving multiple vasopressors. This indicates ongoing septic shock and requires careful monitoring and adjustment of pressor therapy.
2. Respiratory Failure/ARDS: The patient has ARDS secondary to PNA and is on mechanical ventilation. He is tolerating pressure support trials but may require tracheostomy and continued ventilatory support.
3. Leukocytosis/Fever: The patient's fever has resolved, but there is concern for ongoing infection due to the presence of leukocytosis. Cultures should be monitored, and appropriate antibiotic therapy should be continued based on the identified pathogens.
4. Oliguric, Acute on Chronic ARF/Uremia: The patient has acute kidney injury superimposed on chronic kidney disease. He is currently on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) but may require a permanent dial
