   81M with ischemic heart dz EF 30%, p/w septic shock and multiorgan
   failure from CAP PNA complicated by VAP, currently on CVVH w/ ongoing
   pressor requirement. Current infectious issues include C. diff colitis
   and intra-abd fungal/GNR abscess.
   .
   #. Shock/Hypotension:   Was initially hypotensive in setting of septic
   shock.  Had Early Goal Directed Therapy with Apache IV score of 114.
   PNA, C. diff, intra-abdominal abscess are likely sources for sepsis.
   [**Month (only) 60**] also have cardiogenic component to shock as pt has ischemic heart
   disease with EF 20-30%, MvO2 = 52% on [**4-18**], PaO2 26-27 on [**4-21**].  Had
   A-line pulled on [**4-19**] and are unable to obtain central pressure
   monitoring; Has thigh cuff now but insure if cuff BP measurements are
   accurate. On levophed/dobutamine yesterday for poor mentation, elevated
   lactate, but BP did not improve. Switched to levophed/vasopressin and
   able to wean levophed briefly, but then had to add back for precipitous
   BP drop. Did not receive CVVH. Lactate decreased , MvO2 Sat increased,
   and mental status improved today. Continues on Midodrine TID.
   - Attempt to wean levophed/vasopressin as tolerated.
   - Continue to monitor pressure with goal MAP 55, SPB 90.
   .
   #. Resp failure/ ARDS: ARDS secondary to PNA. Patient trached on [**4-1**].
   On Vent, Assist Control. Tolerated PS trial yesterday x 3hrs but back
   on Assist Control per remainder of day.
   - Continue Pressure Support trials as tolerated.
   .
   #.Leukocytosis/fever
 Pt afebrile x 5days. Lactate doubled yesterday,
   repeat BC sent. Completed 11 days of Meropenem for pansensitive
   Serratia and Klebsiella HAP. Abd abscess growing budding yeast,
   pan-[**Last Name (un) **] Serratia, drained w/ IR on [**4-17**], pigtail in place.
   Galactomannin negative; beta-glucan was cancelled due to hemolyzed
   sample.  Started Fluconazole [**4-16**] and [**Last Name (un) **] [**4-19**] for intra-abdominal
   abscess. Switched fluc to micafungin [**4-22**] and gave vanco IV x 1 given
   worsening clinical status.  CT Abd (w/out IV contrast) prelim read
   shows no interval worsening of abscess.
   - Continue Cefepime (Day 1 Cefepime [**2167-4-20**])
   - On PO vanc  and IV flagyl for c. diff. Treat 14 day course for C.
   diff when cefepime is d/c
d again. Pt may ultimately require a taper to
   prevent recurrence.
   - Continue micafungin (Day 1 Micafungin [**2167-4-22**], Day 7 including 6 days
   of Fluconazole) for fungal abscess.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease and an ejection fraction of 30% who presented with septic shock, multi-organ failure, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). He has been in the ICU for several weeks and has developed complications including c. difficile colitis, intra-abdominal fungal/green-nosed bacterial abscess, acute kidney injury/uremia, anemia, coagulopathy, and left upper extremity swelling. The patient's condition has been fluctuating, with periods of improvement followed by setbacks.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Shock/Hypotension: The patient's shock status requires ongoing monitoring and management with pressors such as levophed/vasopressin. Close attention should be given to maintaining a target mean arterial pressure (MAP) of 55-60 mmHg and systolic blood pressure (SBP) of 90 mmHg.

2. Respiratory Failure/ARDS: The patient's ARDS secondary to PNA is a significant concern. Continuous monitoring of oxygenation and ventilation parameters is essential. Pressure support trials should be attempted as tolerated to wean the patient off assist control mode.

3. Leukocytosis/Fever: Despite the patient being afebrile for five days, there is a concern about leukocytosis. Further evaluation is necessary to determine the underlying cause and appropriate treatment.

4. Anemia: The patient

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease, presenting with septic shock and multi-organ dysfunction. He has been diagnosed with ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), C. difficile colitis, and an intra-abdominal fungal/green gram-negative bacterial abscess. The patient's condition remains critical, with ongoing hypotension requiring vasopressor support. He is also experiencing oliguric acute on chronic renal failure, anemia, coagulopathy, left upper extremity swelling, transaminitis, dysphonia, and mental status changes. The patient's medical history includes coronary artery bypass graft surgery and implantable cardioverter-defibrillator placement. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Shock/Hypotension: The patient's hypotension requires continuous monitoring and adjustment of vasopressor therapy to maintain adequate blood pressure and organ perfusion.
2. Respiratory Failure/ARDS: The patient is on mechanical ventilation with assist-control mode due to acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) secondary to pneumonia. Pressure support trials may be attempted as tolerated.
3. Leukocytosis/Fever: Despite being afebrile for five days, the patient's lactate levels have doubled. Repeat blood cultures have been sent, and the patient is being treated for intra-abdominal abscess with fluconazole and micafungin.
4. Oliguric Acute on Chronic ARF/Urem

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with ischemic heart disease, presenting with septic shock, multi-organ dysfunction, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient has been experiencing hypotension, requiring multiple pressor agents, and has had difficulty maintaining stable blood pressure. There have been attempts to wean off the pressors, but the patient's blood pressure remains unstable. The patient has also shown signs of respiratory failure, with ARDS secondary to PNA, and oliguric acute on chronic ARF/uremia.

Medical Complications:
1. Septic Shock: The patient initially presented with septic shock, which is a severe and life-threatening condition caused by an overwhelming immune response to an infection. The patient's blood pressure has been unstable, requiring ongoing pressor support.
2. Multi-Organ Dysfunction: The patient is experiencing multi-organ dysfunction, with involvement of the lungs, kidneys, and liver. This is indicated by the presence of ARDS, oliguric acute on chronic ARF/uremia, and elevated liver enzymes.
3. Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP): The patient has developed VAP, which is a type of lung infection that occurs in patients who are receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient's chest X-ray shows evidence of consolidation and pleural effusions.
4. Abdominal Abscess: The patient had an abdominal abscess, which was drained on [**4-17**]. The abscess was caused by an intra-abdominal fungal/Gram-negative bacterial infection.
5. Coagulopathy: The patient has a coagulopathy, likely due to shock liver, subacute disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), and poor nutrition. The patient's platelet count has been decreasing over time, and they have a positive result for heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).
6. Anemia: The patient has anemia, which is likely due to chronic disease and ongoing hemolysis. The patient's reticulocyte count is appropriate, indicating that the bone marrow is responding to the anemia.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient has left upper extremity swelling, and an ultrasound has been done to rule out DVT. Asymmetric waveforms were observed in the left subclavian vein, which may indicate a possible DVT.
2. Transaminitis: The patient has elevated liver enzymes, indicating possible liver dysfunction. This could be due to shock liver or other underlying causes.
3. Mental Status Changes: The patient has had fluctuating mental status, ranging from alert and oriented to drowsy and poorly responsive. This could be due to sepsis, hypoxia, or other factors.
4. Dysphonia: The patient's voice has been affected by the cuffed tracheostomy tube. This may improve once the cuff size is adjusted or the tube is changed.
5. Tremor: The patient has developed a new resting and action tremor in both hands. This could be due to side effects of levophed, neuropathy, or hypocalcemia.

Overall, the patient presents with multiple medical complications related to sepsis, multi-organ dysfunction, and VAP. Ongoing monitoring and management are necessary to address these complications and improve the patient's condition.

Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease, presenting with septic shock, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and multiorgan failure. He is currently on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) with intermittent pressor requirement. The patient has multiple comorbidities including chronic kidney disease, anemia of chronic disease, coagulopathy, and dysphonia due to a cuffed tracheostomy tube.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Shock/Hypotension: The patient initially presented with septic shock and required early goal-directed therapy. He has a cardiogenic component to shock due to ischemic heart disease with an ejection fraction of 20-30%. The patient's blood pressure should be monitored and maintained with a goal mean arterial pressure (MAP) of 60 mmHg and systolic blood pressure (SBP) of 100 mmHg. If pressors are required, vasopressin should be started first.

2. Respiratory Failure/ARDS: The patient has ARDS secondary to pneumonia and is currently on assist control ventilation. Pressure support trials should be continued as tolerated. The patient may require tracheostomy tube changes, and extubation should be considered when appropriate.

3. Leukocytosis: The patient completed 11 days of meropenem for pan-sensitive Serratia and Klebsiella hospital-acquired pneumonia. He also had an intra-ab

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with ischemic heart disease who was admitted with septic shock. The patient has had a complicated ICU course and currently has several ongoing issues:

1. Hemodynamics and fluid status: The patient intermittently requires pressors to maintain perfusion, but is currently off pressors. CVVH is being continued to remove excess volume as tolerated, and a plan is in place to place a hemodialysis line early next week.

2. Infection: The patient continues to have air & fluid in the abdomen, and a pigtail drain is in place to drain the infection. Cefepime and fluconazole are being continued for the intra-abdominal abscess per ID recs, and PO vancomycin and IV flagyl are being given for C. diff.

3. Anemia: The patient has anemia of chronic disease, and there has been limited benefit from iron supplementation. Folate levels are normal, B12 levels are high, and there is evidence of ongoing hemolysis. The patient tested positive for super Coombs but on repeat testing was negative. It is advised to only transfuse in emergency settings of active ischemia due to a history of delayed transfusion reaction. Blood bank has frozen one unit for this patient and is working to obtain more from the Red Cross.

4. Coagulopathy: The patient has likely component of shock liver, subacute DIC, and poor nutrition. Plate

   Assessment and Plan
   81M with ischemic heart dz EF 30%, p/w septic shock and multiorgan
   failure from CAP PNA complicated by VAP, currently on CVVH w/
   intermittent pressor requirement. Current infectious issues include C.
   diff colitis and intra-abd fungal/GNR abscess.
   .
   #. Shock/Hypotension:   Was initially hypotensive in setting of septic
   shock.  Had Early Goal Directed Therapy with Apache IV score of 114.
   PNA, C. diff, intra-abdominal abscess are likely sources for sepsis.
   [**Month (only) 60**] also have cardiogenic component to shock as pt has ischemic heart
   disease with EF 20-30%, MvO2 = 52% on [**4-18**], PaO2 26-27 on [**4-21**].  Had
   A-line pulled on [**4-19**] and are unable to obtain central pressure
   monitoring; Has thigh cuff now but insure if cuff BP measurements are
   accurate. On levophed/vasopressin yesterday w/ improved mental status
   and decrease in lactate. Able to wean off all pressors overnight.
   Continues on Midodrine TID.
   - Continue to monitor pressure with goal MAP 60, SBP 100. If pressors
   required, start with vasopressin first.
   - Pt may also have blood loss contributing to hypotension. Will recheck
   PM Hct and transfuse prn.
   .
   #. Resp failure/ ARDS: ARDS secondary to PNA. Patient trached on [**4-1**].
   On Vent, Assist Control. Tolerated PS trial yesterday x 5hrs but back
   on Assist Control for remainder of day. Possible evidence RLL PNA on CT
   [**4-22**]. On cefepime, which should cover GNR infection that he previously
   had. New BAL and sputum cultures negative. Will reevaluate if spikes
   fever. [**Month (only) 60**] have component of anxiety contributing to dyspnea. Continue
   zyprexa 5mg daily, prn, for anxiety.
   - Continue Pressure Support trials as tolerated.
   .
   #.Leukocytosis
 Completed 11 days of Meropenem for pansensitive
   Serratia and Klebsiella HAP. Abd abscess growing [**First Name5 (NamePattern1) 188**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 8398**]
   sensitive to Fluc and pan-[**Last Name (un) **] Serratia, drained w/ IR on [**4-17**], pigtail
   in place. Galactomannin negative; beta-glucan was cancelled due to
   hemolyzed sample.  Started Fluconazole [**4-16**] and [**Last Name (un) **] [**4-19**] for
   intra-abdominal abscess. Switched fluc to micafungin [**4-22**] and gave
   vanco IV x 1 given worsening clinical status.  CT Abd (w/out IV
   contrast) prelim read shows no interval worsening of abscess.
   - Continue Cefepime (Day 1 Cefepime [**2167-4-20**]) and fluconazole (Day 1 Fluc
   [**2167-4-16**]) for intra-abd abcess.
   - On PO vanc  and IV flagyl for c. diff. Treat 14 day course for C.
   diff when cefepime is d/c
d again. Pt may ultimately require a taper to
   prevent recurrence.
   - f/u further ID recs
   - f/u final read CT Abdomen.
   - F/U repeat Blood Cx
   - Had regions of hypoattenuation in liver and spleen on [**4-22**] CT
   Abdomen, most likely due to septic infarcts vs. ischemia. No drainable
   fluid noted. We are unable to obtain MRI due to pacemaker to further
   characterize. Will consider repeat CT on Monday, [**4-27**] to look for
   interval change.
   - continue with daily pigtail flushes until abscess resolved on imaging
   or no further drainage.
   .
   #. Oliguric, acute on chronic ARF/Uremia: Baseline Cr 2.3.  Patient in
   ARF from ATN in setting of hypotension. On CVVH and will continue until
   off pressors. Renal U/S obtained due to anuria, and no evidence of
   obstruction found. Per renal, consider adding 12.5g Albumin [**Hospital1 **] to help
   with persistent anasarca. Holding albumin at this time as unsure of
   clinical benefit.
   - Renal following, appreciate further recs
   - Continue EPO
   - If afebrile with continuing decreased WBC count, consider placing
   tunneled line for HD early next week ([**4-27**]).
   - Recheck Albumin today.
   .
   #Anemia
 Patient has anemia of chronic disease, limited benefit from
   iron supp, but little harm to give it. Folate nl, B12 high, evidence of
   ongoing hemolysis b/c has persistently low hapto, high LDH, high D
   Bili. Also evidence low-grade DIC with high FDP, low fibrinogen. Stool
   guaiac negative. Appropriate reticulocytosis. Pt tested super Coombs
   positive (DAT) but on repeat testing on [**4-17**] Coombs neg. Will not repeat
   Super Coombs per Heme. Should only transfuse in emergency settings of
   active ischemia given h/o delayed transfusion reaction. Blood bank has
   1 U frozen for this patient and is working to obtain more from the Red
   Cross. DIC labs worsened today.
   - appreciate heme recs: check hemolysis labs daily, guaiac stool (neg
   thus far); f/u further recs.
   - Continue Procrit, Fe++ po; folate 4mg Qday
   - Recheck PM Hct and transfuse prn.
   .
   #Coagulopathy: Likely component of shock liver, subacute DIC, and poor
   nutrition. Platelets gradually decreasing over the course of the
   hospital stay. Found to be HIT+ [**4-18**], but SRA negative [**4-23**]. **Pt needs
   separate order for platelet count daily.
   - F/U daily coags and correct INR with vitamin K if has signs of
   bleeding or requires procedure.
   - Per heme, suspicion for HIT is quite low. Will not anticoagulate with
   argatroban but will hold heparin for now.
   .
   #Left Upper Extremity Swelling: Resolved today. No evidence DVT on U/S
   but ?distal stenosis of left subclavian.
   - Continue to monitor strength/sensation/pulses in L arm. No
   intervention at this time.
   .
   #Transaminitis: Likely due to shock liver in setting of distributive
   picture with decreased EF. RUQ u/s shows known CBD dialation, s/p
   chole. Stable. Will recheck LFTs today given elevated Alk Phos and
   TBili.
   .
   #Dysphonia
 due to cuffed 8.0 trach
   - Will hold off changing to smaller cuff until resp status improves
   - ENT consult as needed as outpatient, confirmed with ENT and IP on
   [**2167-4-7**]. Got PMV on [**4-6**].
   .
   #Mental Status: Alert and oriented x 3. Mental status improved today.
   Frustrated with long ICU stay and illness. Continue to monitor as
   pressors are weaned.
   - Frequent reorientation; maintain sleep-wake cycle.
   - Hold Ativan. Use Zyprexa PRN for agitation.
   .
   #CV: Stable. CK elevated in the setting of hypovolemia/shock. No
   ischemic EKG changes. .
   CAD: CABG [**2146**] with multiple PCI.  Continue ASA, statin, re-start BB
   when pressures stable.
   PUMP: EF 29%.  Off of pressors, rpt echo EF 25%
   RHYTHM: CHB s/p DDD PCM,ICD in [**2160**]. Not on Warfarin.
   - Maintain on telemetry
   - Maintain Hct >21, ideally >25, but issues with transfusing, see
   above.
   - Continue midodrine.
   .
   #Tremor: Pt has new resting and action tremor in bilateral hands.
   Differential includes side effect of levophed, neuropathy from chronic
   illness, and ongoing hypocalcemia. Given multiple other issues at this
   time, would not be worthwhile to work up tremor with neurology. Will
   continue to monitor and initiate workup if tremor persists after more
   acute issues resolve.
   .

Tube feeds per G-J tube. Replete lytes PRN.

Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with ischemic heart disease, ejection fraction 30%, presenting with septic shock, multiorgan failure from community-acquired pneumonia complicated by ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), currently on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) with intermittent pressor requirement. The patient also has chronic kidney disease (CKD), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), atrial fibrillation with a pacemaker, and a history of cholecystectomy.

The patient's current conditions include:
1. Shock/Hypotension: Initially hypotensive in setting of septic shock. Had early goal-directed therapy with Apache IV score of 114. Pneumonia, Clostridium difficile, and intra-abdominal fungal/gamma-negative rod (GNR) abscess are likely sources for sepsis. The patient also has cardiogenic component to shock as he has ischemic heart disease with ejection fraction 20-30%. On levophed/vasopressin yesterday with improved mental status and decreased lactate. Able to wean off all pressors overnight. Continues on midodrine TID.
2. Respiratory failure/ARDS: ARDS secondary to PNA. Patient tracheostomized on [**Month (only) 1**]. On ventilator, assist control. Tolerated pressure support trial yesterday x 5 hours but back on assist control for remainder

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 64-year-old male admitted to the ICU with septic shock and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient has a history of chronic heart failure, chronic renal failure, anxiety, impaired balance, muscle performance, transfers, ventilation, altered mental status, malnutrition, hyperglycemia, and a previous diagnosis of C. difficile infection.

24-hour events include loosening of the G-tube at the site of skin breakdown, weaning off all pressors, and changes in medication and family history. The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 37.1°C (98.8°F), heart rate of 82 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 118/53 to 141/84 mmHg, respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a set tidal volume of 500 mL, peak inspiratory pressure of 21 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) at 40%. The patient's renal function is being monitored through continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH).

Lab results show elevated white blood cell count, slightly low hemoglobin level, normal platelet count, elevated creatinine levels, and elevated blood glucose levels. Other lab results indicate coagulopathy, lactic acidosis, hypoalbuminemia, elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and electrolyte imbalances.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include worsening of tissue perfusion, further development of coagulopathy, potential relapse of C. difficile infection, progression of chronic heart failure, exacerbation of chronic renal failure, hemolytic anemia, impaired skin integrity, hypotension, anxiety, impaired aerobic capacity/endurance, balance, muscle performance, transfers, ventilation, altered mental status, malnutrition, hyperglycemia, sepsis with organ dysfunction, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).

Please note that this summary is based on the provided information, and additional clinical assessment and investigations may be necessary to determine the exact medical complications that can arise.

   Assessment and Plan
   81M with ischemic heart dz EF 30%, p/w septic shock and multiorgan
   failure from CAP PNA complicated by VAP, currently on CVVH w/
   intermittent pressor requirement. Current infectious issues include C.
   diff colitis and intra-abd fungal/GNR abscess.
   .
   #. Shock/Hypotension:   Was initially hypotensive in setting of septic
   shock.  Had Early Goal Directed Therapy with Apache IV score of 114.
   PNA, C. diff, intra-abdominal abscess are likely sources for sepsis.
   [**Month (only) 60**] also have cardiogenic component to shock as pt has ischemic heart
   disease with EF 20-30%, MvO2 = 52% on [**4-18**], PaO2 26-27 on [**4-21**].  Had
   A-line pulled on [**4-19**] and are unable to obtain central pressure
   monitoring; Has thigh cuff now but insure if cuff BP measurements are
   accurate. On levophed/vasopressin yesterday w/ improved mental status
   and decrease in lactate. Able to wean off all pressors overnight.
   Continues on Midodrine TID.
   - Continue to monitor pressure with goal MAP 60, SBP 100.
   - If pressors required, start with vasopressin first.
   .
   #. Resp failure/ ARDS: ARDS secondary to PNA. Patient trached on [**4-1**].
   On Vent, Assist Control. Tolerated PS trial yesterday x 5hrs but back
   on Assist Control for remainder of day. Possible evidence RLL PNA on CT
   [**4-22**]. On cefepime, which should cover GNR infection that he previously
   had. New BAL and sputum cultures negative. Will reevaluate if spikes
   fever.
   - Continue Pressure Support trials as tolerated.
   .
   #.Leukocytosis
 Completed 11 days of Meropenem for pansensitive
   Serratia and Klebsiella HAP. Abd abscess growing [**First Name5 (NamePattern1) 188**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 8398**]
   sensitive to Fluc and pan-[**Last Name (un) **] Serratia, drained w/ IR on [**4-17**], pigtail
   in place. Galactomannin negative; beta-glucan was cancelled due to
   hemolyzed sample.  Started Fluconazole [**4-16**] and [**Last Name (un) **] [**4-19**] for
   intra-abdominal abscess. Switched fluc to micafungin [**4-22**] and gave
   vanco IV x 1 given worsening clinical status.  CT Abd (w/out IV
   contrast) prelim read shows no interval worsening of abscess.
   - Continue Cefepime (Day 1 Cefepime [**2167-4-20**])
   - On PO vanc  and IV flagyl for c. diff. Treat 14 day course for C.
   diff when cefepime is d/c
d again. Pt may ultimately require a taper to
   prevent recurrence.
   - Continue fluconazole (Day 1 Fluc [**2167-4-16**])
   - f/u ID recs
   - f/u final read CT Abdomen.
   - F/U repeat Blood Cx
   - Had regions of hypoattenuation in liver and spleen on [**4-22**] CT
   Abdomen, most likely due to septic infarcts vs. ischemia. No drainable
   fluid noted. We are unable to obtain MRI due to pacemaker to further
   characterize. Will consider repeat CT on Monday, [**4-27**] to look for
   interval change.
   .
   #. Oliguric, acute on chronic ARF/Uremia: Baseline Cr 2.3.  Patient in
   ARF from acute tubular necrosis in setting of hypotension. On CVVH and
   will continue until off pressors. Renal U/S obtained due to anuria, and
   no evidence of obstruction found. Per renal, consider adding 12.5g
   Albumin [**Hospital1 **] to help with persistent anasarca.
   - Renal following, appreciate recs
   - Continue EPO
   .
   #Anemia
 Patient has anemia of chronic disease, limited benefit from
   iron supp, but little harm to give it. Folate nl, B12 high, evidence of
   ongoing hemolysis b/c has persistently low hapto, high LDH, high D
   Bili. Also evidence low-grade DIC with high FDP, low fibrinogen. Stool
   guaiac negative. Appropriate reticulocytosis. Pt tested super Coombs
   positive (DAT) but on repeat testing on [**4-17**] Coombs neg. Will not repeat
   Super Coombs per Heme. Should only transfuse in emergency settings of
   active ischemia given h/o delayed transfusion reaction. Blood bank has
   1 U frozen for this patient and is working to obtain more from the Red
   Cross.
   - appreciate heme recs: check hemolysis labs daily, guaiac stool (neg
   thus far); f/u further recs.
   - Continue Procrit, Fe++ po; folate 4mg Qday
   .
   #Coagulopathy: Likely component of shock liver, subacute DIC, and poor
   nutrition. Platelets gradually decreasing over the course of the
   hospital stay. Found to be HIT+ [**4-18**], but SRA negative [**4-23**]. **Pt needs
   separate order for platelet count daily.
   - F/U daily coags and correct INR with vitamin K if has signs of
   bleeding or requires procedure.
   - Per heme, suspicion for HIT is quite low. Will not anticoagulate with
   argatroban but will hold heparin for now.
   .
   #Left Upper Extremity Swelling: Left arm again swollen >> right arm.
   Has symmetric strength/sensation in bilateral UE. No evidence DVT on
   U/S but ?distal stenosis of left subclavian.
   - Continue to monitor strength/sensation/pulses in L arm. No
   intervention at this time.
   .
   #Transaminitis: Likely due to shock liver in setting of distributive
   picture with decreased EF. RUQ u/s shows known CBD dialation, s/p
   chole. Stable. Will recheck LFTs today given elevated Alk Phos and
   TBili.
   .
   #Dysphonia
 due to cuffed 8.0 trach
   - Will hold off changing to smaller cuff until resp status improves
   - ENT consult as needed as outpatient, confirmed with ENT and IP on
   [**2167-4-7**]. Got PMV on [**4-6**].
   .
   #Mental Status: Alert and oriented x 3. Mental status improved today.
   Frustrated with long ICU stay and illness. Continue to monitor as
   pressors are weaned.
   - Frequent reorientation; maintain sleep-wake cycle.
   - Hold Ativan. Use  Zyprexa PRN for agitation.
   .
   #CV: Stable. CK elevated in the setting of hypovolemia/shock. No
   ischemic EKG changes. .
   CAD: CABG [**2146**] with multiple PCI.  Continue ASA, statin, re-start BB
   when pressures stable.
   PUMP: EF 29%.  Off of pressors, rpt echo EF 25%
   RHYTHM: CHB s/p DDD PCM,ICD in [**2160**]. Not on Warfarin.
   - Maintain on telemetry
   - Maintain Hct >21, ideally >25, but issues with transfusing, see
   above.
   - Continue midodrine, vasopressin/levophed as needed.
   .
   #Tremor: Pt has new resting and action tremor in bilateral hands.
   Differential includes side effect of levophed, neuropathy from chronic
   illness, and ongoing hypocalcemia. Given multiple other issues at this
   time, would not be worthwhile to work up tremor with neurology. Will
   continue to monitor and initiate workup if tremor persists after more
   acute issues resolve.
   .
   FEN
Tube feeds per G-J tube. Replete lytes PRN.
   PPx
 Pboots, PPI qday. No heparin (HIT+).
   Code
 DNR. Pressors Ok. Patient already trach
   Access
 HD line, PICC.

 MICU for now

The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease, presenting with septic shock, multiorgan failure, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient has been in the ICU for several weeks and has multiple comorbidities, including chronic kidney disease, anemia, coagulopathy, and transaminitis.

The patient's current condition is as follows:
- Vital signs: Tcurrent 35.6°C, HR 82 bpm, BP 118/53 mmHg, RR 30 breaths/min, SpO2 100%.
- Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient was initially hypotensive but is now stable off all pressors.
- Fluid balance: The patient has received a total of 3,075 mL of fluids over the past 24 hours.
- Respiratory support: The patient is on assist-control ventilation with a tidal volume set at 500 mL.
- Neurologic status: The patient is drowsy but arousable, oriented x3, and moving all four extremities.

Medical complications that can arise based on the information provided include:
1. Shock/hypotension: The patient initially presented with septic shock, and there is a concern for cardiogenic shock due to his ischemic heart disease.
2. Respiratory failure/ARDS: The patient has ARDS secondary to pneumonia and is on mechanical ventilation.
3. Leukocytosis: The patient completed

Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease, presenting with septic shock and multiorgan failure secondary to CAP PNA complicated by VAP. The patient has been diagnosed with C. diff colitis, intra-abdominal fungal/GNR abscess, and is currently on CVVH with intermittent pressor requirement. The patient's current infectious issues include C. diff colitis and intra-abdominal abscess. The patient has been weaned off all pressors.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Shock/Hypotension: The patient initially presented with septic shock and required early goal-directed therapy. There is a cardiogenic component to the shock due to the patient's ischemic heart disease with an ejection fraction of 20-30%. The patient had a line pulled and was unable to obtain central pressure monitoring. They are now on midodrine TID and continue to monitor pressure with a goal mean arterial pressure (MAP) of 60 and systolic blood pressure (SBP) of 100. If pressors are required, they will start with vasopressin first.

2. Respiratory Failure/ARDS: The patient has ARDS secondary to PNA and is tracheostomized. They were on assist control ventilation but tolerated a pressure support trial for 5 hours yesterday. New BAL and sputum cultures are negative. They will continue pressure support trials as tolerated.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease, presenting with septic shock, multiorgan failure, acute kidney injury, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and chronic anemia. He has multiple comorbidities including chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), congestive heart failure (CHF), diabetes mellitus type 2, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. The patient has been admitted to the ICU for severe pneumonia with ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). He is currently on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) due to acute kidney injury and is also receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics for various infections, including MRSA and fungal/Gram-negative bacterial abscess.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Shock/hypotension: The patient initially presented with septic shock, which is a life-threatening condition characterized by low blood pressure and inadequate tissue perfusion. This can lead to organ dysfunction and failure if not promptly treated.
2. Respiratory failure/ARDS: The patient's ARDS is secondary to severe pneumonia and is a critical complication that requires close monitoring and support with mechanical ventilation. Complications such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) can further worsen the respiratory status.
3. Oliguric, acute on chronic ARF/uremia: The patient's acute kidney injury may progress to chronic kidney disease (CKD), leading to uremia and requiring ongoing management with dialysis.
4. Anemia: The patient has anemia of chronic disease, which is commonly seen in individuals with long-standing illnesses. It can be exacerbated by acute blood loss or ongoing hemolysis.
5. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulation status is compromised due to liver dysfunction, subacute disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), and malnutrition. This increases the risk of bleeding complications.
6. Left upper extremity swelling: The patient's left arm swelling may indicate deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or subclavian vein thrombosis, which can lead to pulmonary embolism if not treated promptly.
7. Transaminitis: The patient's elevated liver enzymes are likely due to shock liver, but ongoing monitoring is necessary to detect any progression or new causes of liver dysfunction.
8. Mental status changes: The patient's mental status fluctuates due to various factors including sepsis, sedation, and the ICU environment. Close monitoring and appropriate interventions are required to maintain his mental well-being.
9. CV/HF: The patient's cardiac function is compromised, and ongoing monitoring and treatment are necessary to prevent further deterioration.
10. Tremor: The patient's new tremor could be a side effect of medications or a sign of hypocalcemia. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause and appropriate management.

Overall, the patient is facing multiple medical complications that require careful monitoring and management. The priority is to stabilize his hemodynamics, address the infections, and support organ functions.

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is admitted to the ICU with septic shock, ventilator-associated pneumonia, and acute renal failure. The patient's condition has been unstable with fluctuating blood pressures and lactate levels. Vasopressin was restarted due to increasing lactate and borderline blood pressures. Levophed was restarted for persistent mean arterial pressures in the 40s.

The patient developed epigastric pain around 5 am, and the gastrointestinal tube was draining clumpy, maroon fluid. Stool guaiac positive. 

The patient has multiple medical complications including respiratory failure, alteration in tissue perfusion, coagulopathy, Clostridium difficile infection, chronic heart failure, hemolytic anemia, impaired skin integrity, hypotension, anxiety, impaired aerobic capacity/endurance, balance, muscle performance, impaired transfers, impaired ventilation, altered mental status, malnutrition, hyperglycemia, severe sepsis with organ dysfunction, chronic renal failure, and acute respiratory distress syndrome.

ICU care includes nutrition support, glycemic control, lines (dialysis catheter and PICC line), prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis, stress ulcers, and ventilator-associated pneumonia. The patient has a do-not-resuscitate order in place.

   Assessment and Plan
   81M with ischemic heart dz EF 30%, p/w septic shock and multiorgan
   failure from CAP PNA complicated by VAP, currently on CVVH w/
   intermittent pressor requirement. Current infectious issues include C.
   diff colitis and intra-abd fungal/GNR abscess.
   .
   #. Shock/Hypotension:   Was initially hypotensive in setting of septic
   shock.  Had Early Goal Directed Therapy with Apache IV score of 114.
   PNA, C. diff, intra-abdominal abscess are likely sources for sepsis.
   [**Month (only) 60**] also have cardiogenic component to shock as pt has ischemic heart
   disease with EF 20-30%, MvO2 = 52% on [**4-18**], PaO2 26-27 on [**4-21**].  Had
   A-line pulled on [**4-19**] and are unable to obtain central pressure
   monitoring; Has thigh cuff now but insure if cuff BP measurements are
   accurate. On levophed/vasopressin yesterday w/ improved mental status
   and decrease in lactate. Continues on Midodrine TID. Tolerated several
   hours off pressors yesterday, but vasopressin and levophed had to be
   added back.
   -  Attempt to wean pressors as tolerated, with plan to wean levophed
   first.
   - Continue to monitor pressure with goal MAP 60, SBP 100.
   .
   #. Resp failure/ ARDS: ARDS secondary to PNA. Patient trached on [**4-1**].
   On Vent, Assist Control. Tolerated PS trial yesterday x 5hrs but back
   on Assist Control for remainder of day. Possible evidence RLL PNA on CT
   [**4-22**]. On cefepime, which should cover GNR infection that he previously
   had. New BAL and sputum cultures negative. Will reevaluate if spikes
   fever. [**Month (only) 60**] have component of anxiety contributing to dyspnea. Continue
   zyprexa 5mg daily, prn, for anxiety.
   - Continue Pressure Support trials as tolerated.
   .
   #.Leukocytosis
 Completed 11 days of Meropenem for pansensitive
   Serratia and Klebsiella HAP. Abd abscess growing [**First Name5 (NamePattern1) 188**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 8398**]
   sensitive to Fluc and pan-[**Last Name (un) **] Serratia, drained w/ IR on [**4-17**], pigtail
   in place. Galactomannin negative; beta-glucan was cancelled due to
   hemolyzed sample.  Started Fluconazole [**4-16**] and [**Last Name (un) **] [**4-19**] for
   intra-abdominal abscess. Switched fluc to micafungin [**4-22**] and gave
   vanco IV x 1 given worsening clinical status.  CT Abd (w/out IV
   contrast) prelim read shows no interval worsening of abscess.
   - Continue Cefepime (Day 1 Cefepime [**2167-4-20**]) and fluconazole (Day 1 Fluc
   [**2167-4-16**]) for intra-abd abcess.
   - On PO vanc  and IV flagyl for c. diff. Treat 14 day course for C.
   diff when cefepime is d/c
d again. Pt may ultimately require a taper to
   prevent recurrence.
   - f/u further ID recs
   - F/U repeat Blood Cx
   - Had regions of hypoattenuation in liver and spleen on [**4-22**] CT
   Abdomen, most likely due to septic infarcts vs. ischemia. No drainable
   fluid noted. We are unable to obtain MRI due to pacemaker to further
   characterize. Will consider repeat CT on Monday, [**4-27**] to look for
   interval change.
   - continue with daily pigtail flushes until abscess resolved on imaging
   or no further drainage.
   .
   #.Abdominal Pain
 Patient w/ new [**11-21**] abdominal pain this morning.
   Gastric contents changed from bilious to maroon sludge. Stool guaiac
   negative Pigtail output much clearer, green than previously. No nausea.
   LFTS elevated but stable from yesterday, Hct stable, amylase/lipase
   normal. Concern for cholangitis vs new ischemic injury to liver.
   - Consider repeat CT abdomen this AM.
   .
   #. Oliguric, acute on chronic ARF/Uremia: Baseline Cr 2.3.  Patient in
   ARF from ATN in setting of hypotension. On CVVH and will continue until
   off pressors. Renal U/S obtained due to anuria, and no evidence of
   obstruction found. Per renal, consider adding 12.5g Albumin [**Hospital1 **] to help
   with persistent anasarca. Holding albumin at this time as unsure of
   clinical benefit.
   - Renal following, appreciate further recs
   - Continue EPO
   - If afebrile with continuing decreased WBC count, consider placing
   tunneled line for HD early next week ([**4-27**]).
   - Recheck Albumin today.
   .
   #Anemia
 Patient has anemia of chronic disease, limited benefit from
   iron supp, but little harm to give it. Folate nl, B12 high, evidence of
   ongoing hemolysis b/c has persistently low hapto, high LDH, high D
   Bili. Also evidence low-grade DIC with high FDP, low fibrinogen. Stool
   guaiac negative. Appropriate reticulocytosis. Pt tested super Coombs
   positive (DAT) but on repeat testing on [**4-17**] Coombs neg. Will not repeat
   Super Coombs per Heme. Should only transfuse in emergency settings of
   active ischemia given h/o delayed transfusion reaction. Blood bank has
   1 U frozen for this patient and is working to obtain more from the Red
   Cross. DIC labs worsened today.
   - appreciate heme recs: check hemolysis labs daily, guaiac stool (neg
   thus far); f/u further recs.
   - Continue Procrit, Fe++ po; folate 4mg Qday
   - Recheck PM Hct and transfuse prn.
   .
   #Coagulopathy: Likely component of shock liver, subacute DIC, and poor
   nutrition. Platelets gradually decreasing over the course of the
   hospital stay. Found to be HIT+ [**4-18**], but SRA negative [**4-23**]. **Pt needs
   separate order for platelet count daily.
   - F/U daily coags and correct INR with vitamin K if has signs of
   bleeding or requires procedure.
   - Per heme, suspicion for HIT is quite low. Will not anticoagulate with
   argatroban but will hold heparin for now.
   .
   #Left Upper Extremity Swelling: Resolved today. No evidence DVT on U/S
   but ?distal stenosis of left subclavian.
   - Continue to monitor strength/sensation/pulses in L arm. No
   intervention at this time.
   .
   #Transaminitis: Likely due to shock liver in setting of distributive
   picture with decreased EF. RUQ u/s shows known CBD dialation, s/p
   chole. Stable. Will recheck LFTs today given elevated Alk Phos and
   TBili.
   .
   #Dysphonia
 due to cuffed 8.0 trach
   - Will hold off changing to smaller cuff until resp status improves
   - ENT consult as needed as outpatient, confirmed with ENT and IP on
   [**2167-4-7**]. Got PMV on [**4-6**].
   .
   #Mental Status: Alert and oriented x 3. Mental status improved today.
   Frustrated with long ICU stay and illness. Continue to monitor as
   pressors are weaned.
   - Frequent reorientation; maintain sleep-wake cycle.
   - Hold Ativan. Use Zyprexa PRN for agitation.
   .
   #CV: Stable. CK elevated in the setting of hypovolemia/shock. No
   ischemic EKG changes. .
   CAD: CABG [**2146**] with multiple PCI.  Continue ASA, statin, re-start BB
   when pressures stable.
   PUMP: EF 29%.  Off of pressors, rpt echo EF 25%
   RHYTHM: CHB s/p DDD PCM,ICD in [**2160**]. Not on Warfarin.
   - Maintain on telemetry
   - Maintain Hct >21, ideally >25, but issues with transfusing, see
   above.
   - Continue midodrine.
   .
   #Tremor: Pt has new resting and action tremor in bilateral hands.
   Differential includes side effect of levophed, neuropathy from chronic
   illness, and ongoing hypocalcemia. Given multiple other issues at this
   time, would not be worthwhile to work up tremor with neurology. Will
   continue to monitor and initiate workup if tremor persists after more
   acute issues resolve.
   .
   FEN
Tube feeds per G-J tube. Replete lytes PRN.
   PPx
 Pboots, PPI qday. No heparin (HIT+).
   Code
 DNR. Pressors Ok. Patient already trach
   Access
 HD line, PICC.
   Dispo
 MICU for now

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease, presenting with septic shock, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), acute renal failure, and multiorgan failure. The patient has been admitted to the ICU for several weeks and has multiple medical complications, including leukocytosis, abdominal pain, anemia, coagulopathy, left upper extremity swelling, transaminitis, dysphonia, mental status changes, cardiovascular instability, and tremor.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Shock/Hypotension: The patient initially presented with hypotension in the setting of septic shock. There is a cardiogenic component to the shock due to the patient's ischemic heart disease. The patient requires ongoing pressor support and careful monitoring of blood pressure.

2. Respiratory Failure/ARDS: The patient developed ARDS secondary to pneumonia. The patient has been intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation with assist-control mode. The patient tolerated a pressure support trial but was placed back on assist-control mode for the remainder of the day. A possible evidence of right lower lobe pneumonia was noted on a recent CT scan.

3. Leukocytosis: The patient completed 11 days of meropenem for pan-sensitive Serratia and Klebsiella hospital-acquired pneumonia. The patient also has an intra-abdominal abscess that is sensitive to fluconazole and vancomycin. The patient's leukocyte

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease, presenting with septic shock, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), acute renal failure, and multiorgan failure. He has been diagnosed with Clostridium difficile colitis and intra-abdominal fungal and Gram-negative bacterial abscesses. The patient is currently on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) and intermittent pressor support. He has been experiencing abdominal pain, which could be due to cholangitis or a new ischemic injury to the liver. The patient also has anemia of chronic disease, low-grade disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), and a positive super Coombs test. He is HIT positive but SRA negative. 

Potential medical complications:
1. Shock/hypotension: The patient initially presented with hypotension in the setting of septic shock. There is a cardiogenic component to the shock due to the patient's ischemic heart disease. The patient continues to require pressor support, and efforts are being made to wean the pressors as tolerated.
2. Respiratory failure/ARDS: The patient has ARDS secondary to pneumonia. He is on ventilatory support and has been tracheostomized. Pressure support trials are being attempted as tolerated.
3. Leukocytosis: The patient completed 11 days of meropenem for pan-sensitive Serratia and Klebsi

   Assessment and Plan
   81M with ischemic heart dz EF 30%, p/w septic shock and multiorgan
   failure from CAP PNA complicated by VAP, currently on CVVH w/
   intermittent pressor requirement. Current infectious issues include C.
   diff colitis and intra-abd fungal/GNR abscess.
   .
   #. Shock/Hypotension:   Was initially hypotensive in setting of septic
   shock.  Had Early Goal Directed Therapy with Apache IV score of 114.
   PNA, C. diff, intra-abdominal abscess are likely sources for sepsis.
   [**Month (only) 60**] also have cardiogenic component to shock as pt has ischemic heart
   disease with EF 20-30%, MvO2 = 52% on [**4-18**], PaO2 26-27 on [**4-21**].  Had
   A-line pulled on [**4-19**] and are unable to obtain central pressure
   monitoring; Has thigh cuff now but insure if cuff BP measurements are
   accurate. On levophed/vasopressin yesterday w/ improved mental status
   and decrease in lactate. Continues on Midodrine TID. Tolerated several
   hours off pressors yesterday, but vasopressin and levophed had to be
   added back.
   -  Attempt to wean pressors as tolerated, with plan to wean levophed
   first.
   - Continue to monitor pressure with goal MAP 60, SBP 100.
   .
   #. Resp failure/ ARDS: ARDS secondary to PNA. Patient trached on [**4-1**].
   On Vent, Assist Control. Has tolerated a few hours of PS each day.
   Possible evidence RLL PNA on CT [**4-22**]. On cefepime, which should cover
   GNR infection that he previously had. New BAL and sputum cultures
   negative. Will reevaluate if spikes fever. [**Month (only) 60**] have component of
   anxiety contributing to dyspnea. Continue zyprexa 5mg [**Hospital1 **], prn, for
   anxiety.
   - Continue Pressure Support trials as tolerated.
   .
   #.Leukocytosis
 Completed 11 days of Meropenem for pansensitive
   Serratia and Klebsiella HAP. Abd abscess growing [**First Name5 (NamePattern1) 188**] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 8398**]
   sensitive to Fluc and pan-[**Last Name (un) **] Serratia, drained w/ IR on [**4-17**], pigtail
   in place. Galactomannin negative; beta-glucan was cancelled due to
   hemolyzed sample.  Started Fluconazole [**4-16**] and [**Last Name (un) **] [**4-19**] for
   intra-abdominal abscess. Switched fluc to micafungin [**4-22**] and gave
   vanco IV x 1 given worsening clinical status.  CT Abd (w/out IV
   contrast) [**4-22**] showed smaller air and fluid collection adjacent to
   duodenum.
   - Continue Cefepime (Day 1 Cefepime [**2167-4-20**]) and fluconazole (Day 1 Fluc
   [**2167-4-16**]) for intra-abdominal abscess.
   - On PO vanc and IV flagyl for c. diff. Treat 14 day course for C. diff
   when cefepime is d/c
d again. Pt may ultimately require a taper to
   prevent recurrence.
   - F/U further ID recs
   - F/U repeat Blood Cx
   - Had regions of hypoattenuation in liver and spleen on [**4-22**] CT
   Abdomen, most likely due to septic infarcts vs. ischemia. No drainable
   fluid noted. We are unable to obtain MRI due to pacemaker to further
   characterize. Given abdominal pain today, will repeat CT Abdomen today
   to look for interval change in these lesions.
   - continue with daily pigtail flushes until abscess resolved on imaging
   or no further drainage.
   .
   #.Abdominal Pain
 Patient w/ new [**11-21**] abdominal pain this morning.
   Gastric contents changed from bilious to maroon sludge, gastro-occult
   positive. Stool guaiac negative. Pigtail output much clearer, green
   than previously. No nausea. LFTS elevated but stable from yesterday,
   Hct stable, amylase/lipase normal. Has had elevated transaminases
   earlier in hospital course likely due to shock liver. New concern for
   gastric ulcer, cholangitis, diverticulitis +/- perforation, vs new
   ischemic injury to liver. Morphine/Dilaudid prn for pain.
   - Hold Tube Feeds for now.
   - Obtain KUB.
   - Repeat CT abdomen this AM with PO/IV contrast. Will need PIV placed
   today for IV contrast.
   - Surgery consult as needed.
   .
   #. Oliguric, acute on chronic ARF/Uremia: Baseline Cr 2.3.  Patient in
   ARF from ATN in setting of hypotension. On CVVH and will continue until
   off pressors. Renal U/S obtained due to anuria, and no evidence of
   obstruction found. Per renal, consider adding 12.5g Albumin [**Hospital1 **] to help
   with anasarca. Holding albumin at this time as unsure of clinical
   benefit and peripheral edema dramatically improved today. Albumin [**4-24**]
   1.7, likely nutritional.
   - Renal following, appreciate further recs
   - Continue EPO
   - Continue CVVH with I/O even today give decreased edema and
   hypotension.
   - If afebrile with continuing decreased WBC count, consider placing
   tunneled line for HD early next week ([**4-27**]).
   .
   #Anemia
 Patient has anemia of chronic disease, limited benefit from
   iron supp, but little harm to give it. Folate nl, B12 high, evidence of
   ongoing hemolysis b/c has persistently low hapto, high LDH, high D
   Bili. Also evidence low-grade DIC with high FDP, low fibrinogen. Stool
   guaiac negative. Appropriate reticulocytosis. Pt tested super Coombs
   positive (DAT) but on repeat testing on [**4-17**] Coombs neg. Will not repeat
   Super Coombs per Heme. Should only transfuse in emergency settings of
   active ischemia given h/o delayed transfusion reaction. Blood bank has
   1 U frozen for this patient and is working to obtain more from the Red
   Cross. DIC labs worsened yesterday.
   - appreciate heme recs: check hemolysis labs daily, guaiac stool ; f/u
   further recs.
   - Continue Procrit, Fe++ po; folate 4mg Qday
   .
   #Coagulopathy: Likely component of shock liver, subacute DIC, and poor
   nutrition. Platelets gradually decreasing over the course of the
   hospital stay. Found to be HIT+ [**4-18**], but SRA negative [**4-23**]. **Pt needs
   separate order for platelet count daily.
   - F/U daily coags and correct INR with vitamin K if has signs of
   bleeding or requires procedure.
   - Follow DIC labs daily. Per heme, if fibrinogen < 100, give cryo.
   Spoke with Blood Bank and Pt should not have issues receiving cryo
   transfusions.
   - Per heme, suspicion for HIT is quite low. Will not anticoagulate with
   argatroban but will hold heparin for now.
   .
   #Left Upper Extremity Swelling: Resolved. No evidence DVT on U/S x 2
   but ?distal stenosis of left subclavian.
   - Continue to monitor strength/sensation/pulses in L arm. No
   intervention at this time.
   .
   #Dysphonia
 due to cuffed 8.0 trach
   - Will hold off changing to smaller cuff until resp status improves
   - ENT consult as needed as outpatient, confirmed with ENT and IP on
   [**2167-4-7**]. Got PMV on [**4-6**].
   .
   #Mental Status: Alert and oriented x 3. Mental status improved today.
   Frustrated with long ICU stay and illness. Continue to monitor as
   pressors are weaned.
   - Frequent reorientation; maintain sleep-wake cycle.
   - Hold Ativan. Use Zyprexa [**Hospital1 **]:PRN for agitation.
   .
   #CV: Stable. CK elevated in the setting of hypovolemia/shock. No
   ischemic EKG changes.  Will recheck CK today given ongoing hypotension.
   CAD: CABG [**2146**] with multiple PCI.  Continue ASA, statin, re-start BB
   when pressures stable.
   PUMP: EF 29%.  Off of pressors, rpt echo EF 25%
   RHYTHM: CHB s/p DDD PCM,ICD in [**2160**]. Not on Warfarin.
   - Maintain on telemetry
   - Maintain Hct >21, ideally >25, but issues with transfusing, see
   above.
   - Continue midodrine, levophed/vasopressin as needed.
   .
   #Tremor: Pt has new resting and action tremor in bilateral hands.
   Differential includes side effect of levophed, neuropathy from chronic
   illness, and ongoing hypocalcemia. Given multiple other issues at this
   time, would not be worthwhile to work up tremor with neurology. Will
   continue to monitor and initiate workup if tremor persists after more
   acute issues resolve.
   .
   FEN
 Holding Tube feeds per G-J tube pending workup of new abd pain.
   Replete lytes PRN.
   PPx
 Pboots, PPI qday. No heparin (HIT+). Foam support for relief of
   pressure ulcer on back of head.
   Code
 DNR. Pressors Ok. Patient already trach
   Access
 HD line, PICC.
   Dispo
 MICU for now

Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease and a low ejection fraction (EF 30%), who was admitted with septic shock and multiorgan failure secondary to pneumonia and ventilator-associated pneumonia. The patient has been on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH) and has required intermittent use of vasopressors due to persistent hypotension. He also has acute renal failure and anemia of chronic disease with ongoing hemolysis and evidence of low-grade disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Shock/Hypotension: The patient has been experiencing hypotension and requires vasopressors to maintain adequate blood pressure. There is a concern for cardiogenic shock due to his history of ischemic heart disease and reduced EF.
2. Respiratory Failure/ARDS: The patient developed ARDS secondary to pneumonia and is currently on mechanical ventilation. There may be a need for tracheostomy and weaning off ventilatory support.
3. Leukocytosis: The patient had an elevated white blood cell count initially, indicating an infection. He has completed 11 days of meropenem for pan-sensitive Serratia and Klebsiella hospital-acquired pneumonia. However, there is still a concern for intra-abdominal abscess, for which he is receiving fluconazole and micafungin.
4. Abdominal Pain: The patient recently developed new abdominal

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is experiencing multiple medical complications. Some of the potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Septic shock: The patient is currently in septic shock, which is a life-threatening condition caused by an overwhelming infection leading to systemic inflammation and organ dysfunction.

2. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is on mechanical ventilation, and there is a risk of developing VAP, a type of lung infection that occurs in patients who are receiving mechanical ventilation.

3. Acute renal failure: The patient has impaired kidney function, as indicated by elevated levels of creatinine and blood urea nitrogen (BUN). This can lead to fluid overload and electrolyte imbalances.

4. Coagulopathy: The patient has a prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and partial thromboplastin time (PTT), indicating a disorder of blood clotting. This can increase the risk of bleeding or thrombosis.

5. Clostridium difficile infection (CDI): The patient has symptoms consistent with CDI, including diarrhea and positive stool guaiac test. CDI is a common cause of antibiotic-associated colitis.

6. Chronic heart failure: The patient has a history of chronic heart failure, which may contribute to fluid retention and respiratory compromise.

7. Impaired skin integrity: The patient has decreased mobility and pressure ulcers, indicating impaired skin integrity.

The patient is a 81-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease, presenting with septic shock, ventilator-associated pneumonia, and acute renal failure. The patient is currently in the ICU and has been experiencing multiple complications.

Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient was initially hypotensive in the setting of septic shock. Early Goal Directed Therapy was initiated, and the Apache IV score was 114. Possible sources for sepsis include PNA, C. diff, and intra-abdominal abscess.
- The patient has ARDS secondary to PNA and is on ventilatory support. There is evidence of right lower lobe pneumonia on CT scan.
- The patient completed 11 days of meropenem for pan-sensitive Serratia and Klebsiella HAP. An intra-abdominal abscess was drained on 4/17, and the patient started fluconazole on 4/16. The abscess culture was negative for galactomannan but positive for [Last Name (un)]. The patient switched from fluc to micafungin on 4/22 and received vancomycin IV once due to worsening clinical status. A CT abdomen showed smaller air and fluid collection adjacent to the duodenum.
- The patient developed new abdominal pain this morning, with gastric contents changing from bilious to maroon sludge, gastrocult positive. Stool guaiac was negative. Pigtail output was clearer, green than previously

Summary:
Summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

- The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease and an ejection fraction of 30%.
- He was admitted with septic shock and multiorgan failure secondary to community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) complicated by ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
- The patient also has acute renal failure (ARF) due to acute tubular necrosis (ATN) and is currently on continuous renal replacement therapy (CVVH).
- He has been diagnosed with Clostridium difficile (C. diff) colitis and an intra-abdominal fungal/gamma-negative rod (GNR) abscess.
- The patient's hemodynamics are unstable, requiring multiple vasopressors.
- His respiratory status has improved, but he still requires mechanical ventilation.
- The patient has experienced episodes of oliguria and anemia of chronic disease with ongoing hemolysis.
- He has a coagulopathy likely due to shock liver, subacute disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), and poor nutrition.
- The patient has edema and a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).
- He has dysphonia due to a cuffed tracheostomy tube.
- The patient's mental status has fluctuated but is currently alert and oriented.
- His cardiovascular status is stable, but he has a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and previous percutaneous coronary

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is an 82-year-old man with a history of dilated cardiomyopathy, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), renal failure, and severe shock. He has been admitted to the ICU due to respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation and vasopressor support. The patient also has an abdominal abscess with gram-negative and fungal infection, and is undergoing continuous venovenous hemofiltration (CVVH) for renal failure.

24-Hour Events:
- The patient's condition remains critical, with ongoing septic shock requiring vasopressin and norepinephrine infusion.
- Respiratory support has been maintained with tracheostomy and mechanical ventilation.
- Fluid balance shows a negative balance, indicating ongoing attempts to remove excess fluid.
- The patient has developed new abdominal tenderness, which may be due to cholangitis, peritonitis from an abscess, or hepatic abscess. A CT scan of the abdomen with contrast is planned to further evaluate this.
- Renal failure continues, and the patient remains on CVVH.
- Anemia is present, with positive Coombs test, making transfusion challenging.
- The patient has tested positive for PF4 antibodies but negative for serotonin release assay.

Laboratory Results:
- Blood tests show elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, elevated platelet count, elevated creatinine, and abnormal liver function tests.
- Electrolyte levels are within normal range

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease and a recent hospitalization for septic shock and multiorgan failure. He currently presents with abdominal pain, oliguric renal failure, anemia, coagulopathy, and left upper extremity swelling. The patient has been diagnosed with C. diff colitis, intra-abdominal fungal/GNR abscess, and has undergone multiple interventions including tracheostomy, coronary artery bypass surgery, and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube placement. The patient's current condition is complicated by several factors including sepsis, multiorgan dysfunction, and various comorbidities.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Shock/Hypotension: The patient initially presented with septic shock and continues to require intermittent pressor support. There is a concern for cardiogenic shock due to the patient's ischemic heart disease.
2. Respiratory Failure/ARDS: The patient has developed ARDS secondary to pneumonia and is currently on mechanical ventilation. There is evidence of right lower lobe pneumonia on the CT scan.
3. Abdominal Pain: The patient presents with new-onset abdominal pain, which is concerning for gastric ulcer, cholangitis, diverticulitis +/- perforation, or ischemic injury to the liver. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause.
4. Leukocytosis: The patient has leukocytosis likely secondary to infection and inflammation

Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease, presenting with septic shock and multiorgan failure secondary to community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) complicated by ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), currently on continuous veno-venous hemodialysis (CVVH) with intermittent pressor requirement. The patient's infectious issues include Clostridium difficile colitis and intra-abdominal fungal/green necrotic abscess. 

The patient has been diagnosed with leukocytosis, oliguric acute on chronic acute renal failure/uremia, anemia of chronic disease with evidence of ongoing hemolysis, low-grade disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), and coagulopathy likely due to shock liver, subacute DIC, and poor nutrition. The patient also has left upper extremity swelling, dysphonia due to cuffed tracheostomy, and mental status changes.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36 degrees Celsius, heart rate of 73 beats per minute, blood pressure of 118/70 mmHg, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on the ventilator. The patient's physical examination reveals scattered rhonchi throughout bilateral lower lung fields, tenderness and guarding in the epigastric and right upper quadrant, and large stage 1-2 pressure ulcer on the back of the head.

   Assessment and Plan
   81M with ischemic heart dz EF 30%, p/w septic shock and multiorgan
   failure from CAP PNA complicated by VAP, currently on CVVH w/
   intermittent pressor requirement. Current infectious issues include C.
   diff colitis and intra-abd fungal/GNR abscess.

   #. Shock/Hypotension:   Was initially hypotensive in setting of septic
   shock.  Had Early Goal Directed Therapy with Apache IV score of 114.
   PNA, C. diff, intra-abdominal abscess are likely sources for sepsis.
   [**Month (only) 60**] also have cardiogenic component to shock as pt has ischemic heart
   disease with EF 20-30%, MvO2 = 52% on [**4-18**], PaO2 26-27 on [**4-21**].  Had
   A-line pulled on [**4-19**] and are unable to obtain central pressure
   monitoring; Has thigh cuff now but insure if cuff BP measurements are
   accurate. On levophed/vasopressin yesterday w/ improved mental status
   and decrease in lactate. Continues on Midodrine TID. Tolerated several
   hours off pressors yesterday, but vasopressin and levophed had to be
   added back.
   -  Attempt to wean pressors as tolerated, with plan to wean levophed
   first.
   - Continue to monitor pressure with goal MAP 60, SBP 100.
   .
   #. Resp failure/ ARDS: ARDS secondary to PNA. Patient trached on [**4-1**].
   On Vent, Assist Control. Has tolerated a few hours of PS each day.
   Possible evidence RLL PNA on CT [**4-22**]. On cefepime, which should cover
   GNR infection that he previously had. New BAL and sputum cultures
   negative. Will reevaluate if spikes fever. [**Month (only) 60**] have component of
   anxiety contributing to dyspnea. Continue zyprexa 5mg [**Hospital1 **], prn, for
   anxiety.
   - Continue Pressure Support trials as tolerated.
   .

   in place. Galactomannin negative; beta-glucan was cancelled due to
   hemolyzed sample.  Started Fluconazole [**4-16**] and [**Last Name (un) **] [**4-19**] for
   intra-abdominal abscess. Switched fluc to micafungin [**4-22**] and gave
   vanco IV x 1 given worsening clinical status.  CT Abd (w/out IV
   contrast) [**4-22**] showed smaller air and fluid collection adjacent to
   duodenum.
   - Continue Cefepime (Day 1 Cefepime [**2167-4-20**]) and fluconazole (Day 1 Fluc
   [**2167-4-16**]) for intra-abdominal abscess.
   - On PO vanc and IV flagyl for c. diff. Treat 14 day course for C. diff
   when cefepime is d/c
d again. Pt may ultimately require a taper to
   prevent recurrence.
   - F/U further ID recs
   - F/U repeat Blood Cx
   - Had regions of hypoattenuation in liver and spleen on [**4-22**] CT
   Abdomen, most likely due to septic infarcts vs. ischemia. No drainable
   fluid noted. We are unable to obtain MRI due to pacemaker to further
   characterize. Given abdominal pain today, will repeat CT Abdomen today
   to look for interval change in these lesions.
   - continue with daily pigtail flushes until abscess resolved on imaging
   or no further drainage.
   .
   #.Abdominal Pain
 Patient w/ new [**11-21**] abdominal pain this morning.
   Gastric contents changed from bilious to maroon sludge, gastro-occult
   positive. Stool guaiac negative. Pigtail output much clearer, green
   than previously. No nausea. LFTS elevated but stable from yesterday,
   Hct stable, amylase/lipase normal. Has had elevated transaminases
   earlier in hospital course likely due to shock liver. New concern for
   gastric ulcer, cholangitis, diverticulitis +/- perforation, vs new
   ischemic injury to liver. Morphine/Dilaudid prn for pain.
   - Hold Tube Feeds for now.
   - Obtain KUB.
   - Repeat CT abdomen this AM with PO/IV contrast. Will need PIV placed
   today for IV contrast.
   - Surgery consult as needed.
   .
   #. Oliguric, acute on chronic ARF/Uremia: Baseline Cr 2.3.  Patient in
   ARF from ATN in setting of hypotension. On CVVH and will continue until
   off pressors. Renal U/S obtained due to anuria, and no evidence of
   obstruction found. Per renal, consider adding 12.5g Albumin [**Hospital1 **] to help
   with anasarca. Holding albumin at this time as unsure of clinical
   benefit and peripheral edema dramatically improved today. Albumin [**4-24**]
   1.7, likely nutritional.
   - Renal following, appreciate further recs
   - Continue EPO
   - Continue CVVH with I/O even today give decreased edema and
   hypotension.
   - If afebrile with continuing decreased WBC count, consider placing
   tunneled line for HD early next week ([**4-27**]).
   .
   #Anemia
 Patient has anemia of chronic disease, limited benefit from
   iron supp, but little harm to give it. Folate nl, B12 high, evidence of
   ongoing hemolysis b/c has persistently low hapto, high LDH, high D
   Bili. Also evidence low-grade DIC with high FDP, low fibrinogen. Stool
   guaiac negative. Appropriate reticulocytosis. Pt tested super Coombs
   positive (DAT) but on repeat testing on [**4-17**] Coombs neg. Will not repeat
   Super Coombs per Heme. Should only transfuse in emergency settings of
   active ischemia given h/o delayed transfusion reaction. Blood bank has
   1 U frozen for this patient and is working to obtain more from the Red
   Cross. DIC labs worsened yesterday.
   - appreciate heme recs: check hemolysis labs daily, guaiac stool ; f/u
   further recs.
   - Continue Procrit, Fe++ po; folate 4mg Qday
   .
   #Coagulopathy: Likely component of shock liver, subacute DIC, and poor
   nutrition. Platelets gradually decreasing over the course of the
   hospital stay. Found to be HIT+ [**4-18**], but SRA negative [**4-23**]. **Pt needs
   separate order for platelet count daily.
   - F/U daily coags and correct INR with vitamin K if has signs of
   bleeding or requires procedure.
   - Follow DIC labs daily. Per heme, if fibrinogen < 100, give cryo.
   Spoke with Blood Bank and Pt should not have issues receiving cryo
   transfusions.
   - Per heme, suspicion for HIT is quite low. Will not anticoagulate with
   argatroban but will hold heparin for now.
   .
   #Left Upper Extremity Swelling: Resolved. No evidence DVT on U/S x 2
   but ?distal stenosis of left subclavian.
   - Continue to monitor strength/sensation/pulses in L arm. No
   intervention at this time.
   .
   #Dysphonia
 due to cuffed 8.0 trach
   - Will hold off changing to smaller cuff until resp status improves
   - ENT consult as needed as outpatient, confirmed with ENT and IP on
   [**2167-4-7**]. Got PMV on [**4-6**].
   .
   #Mental Status: Alert and oriented x 3. Mental status improved today.
   Frustrated with long ICU stay and illness. Continue to monitor as
   pressors are weaned.
   - Frequent reorientation; maintain sleep-wake cycle.
   - Hold Ativan. Use Zyprexa [**Hospital1 **]:PRN for agitation.
   .
   #CV: Stable. CK elevated in the setting of hypovolemia/shock. No
   ischemic EKG changes.  Will recheck CK today given ongoing hypotension.
   CAD: CABG [**2146**] with multiple PCI.  Continue ASA, statin, re-start BB
   when pressures stable.
   PUMP: EF 29%.  Off of pressors, rpt echo EF 25%
   RHYTHM: CHB s/p DDD PCM,ICD in [**2160**]. Not on Warfarin.
   - Maintain on telemetry
   - Maintain Hct >21, ideally >25, but issues with transfusing, see
   above.
   - Continue midodrine, levophed/vasopressin as needed.
   .
   #Tremor: Pt has new resting and action tremor in bilateral hands.
   Differential includes side effect of levophed, neuropathy from chronic
   illness, and ongoing hypocalcemia. Given multiple other issues at this
   time, would not be worthwhile to work up tremor with neurology. Will
   continue to monitor and initiate workup if tremor persists after more
   acute issues resolve.
   .

 Holding Tube feeds per G-J tube pending workup of new abd pain.

 Pboots, PPI qday. No heparin (HIT+). Foam support for relief of

 DNR. Pressors Ok. Patient already trach

Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease and a recent hospitalization for septic shock and multiorgan failure. He is currently on mechanical ventilation in the ICU due to ARDS secondary to pneumonia. The patient has several ongoing medical complications, including leukocytosis, abdominal pain, oliguric acute on chronic ARF/uremia, anemia, coagulopathy, left upper extremity swelling, dysphonia, and tremor.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Shock/Hypotension: The patient has been hypotensive in the setting of septic shock and requires pressor support. There is a concern for cardiogenic shock due to his ischemic heart disease, but the patient's mental status and lactate levels have improved with the use of vasopressin and levophed.

2. Respiratory Failure/ARDS: The patient has ARDS secondary to pneumonia and is on mechanical ventilation. He has tolerated pressure support trials but requires ongoing ventilatory support.

3. Leukocytosis: The patient completed 11 days of meropenem for pan-sensitive Serratia and Klebsiella hospital-acquired pneumonia. He now has an intra-abdominal fungal/GNR abscess and is being treated with fluconazole and micafungin.

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease, presenting with septic shock and multiorgan failure. The patient has been diagnosed with CAP (community-acquired pneumonia), complicated by ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), C. difficile colitis, and intra-abdominal fungal/green nail bacteria (GNR) abscess. The patient is currently on CVVH (continuous veno-venous hemofiltration) with intermittent pressor requirement. The patient's current medical issues include shock/hypotension, respiratory failure/ARDS, leukocytosis, oliguric acute on chronic ARF/uremia, anemia, coagulopathy, left upper extremity swelling, dysphonia, mental status changes, cardiovascular stability, and tremor.

2. Respiratory Failure/ARDS: The patient developed ARDS secondary to pneumonia and has been intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation. The patient

Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease, presenting with septic shock and multiorgan failure secondary to community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) complicated by ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient also has C. diff colitis and an intra-abdominal fungal/gamma-negatives (GNR) abscess. He is currently on continuous veno-venous hemofiltration (CVVH) with intermittent pressor requirement.

Assessment and plan:
1. Shock/Hypotension: The patient initially presented with hypotension in the setting of septic shock. Early goal-directed therapy was initiated with an Apache IV score of 114. The sources of sepsis are likely to be PNA, C. diff, and intra-abdominal abscess. There is also a cardiogenic component to the shock due to the patient's ischemic heart disease with an ejection fraction of 20-30%. The patient had an arterial line pulled on [**4-19**], and central pressure monitoring is not available. The patient is on levophed/vasopressin and has shown improved mental status and decreased lactate. Pressors should be weaned as tolerated, with the goal of maintaining a mean arterial pressure (MAP) of 60 mmHg and systolic blood pressure (SBP) of 100 mmHg.

2. Respiratory failure/ARDS: The patient has ARDS

Summary:
The patient is an 81-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease, presenting with septic shock and multiorgan failure from community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) complicated by ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient has been in the ICU for an extended period and has developed several complications, including abdominal pain, leukocytosis, oliguric acute on chronic acute renal failure (ARF), anemia, coagulopathy, left upper extremity swelling, dysphonia, mental status changes, and tremors.

The patient's abdominal pain is a new concern since yesterday morning. The gastric contents have changed from bilious to maroon sludge, and there is a positive guaiac test. The pigtail output is much clearer, green than previously. No nausea is present, and the liver function tests (LFTs) are stable. However, there are elevated transaminases earlier in the hospital course, likely due to shock liver. The concern now is for gastric ulcer, cholangitis, diverticulitis +/- perforation, or new ischemic injury to the liver.

The patient has completed 11 days of meropenem for pan-sensitive Serratia and Klebsiella hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP). An intra-abdominal abscess is growing Candida albicans sensitive to fluconazole, which was started on day 1. The CT abdomen without IV contrast on day 22 showed smaller air and fluid collection adjacent

   Bili. Also evidence low-grade DIC with high FDP, low fibrinogen. Stool
   guaiac negative. Appropriate reticulocytosis. Pt tested super Coombs
   positive (DAT) but on repeat testing on [**4-17**] Coombs neg. Will not repeat
   Super Coombs per Heme. Should only transfuse in emergency settings of
   active ischemia given h/o delayed transfusion reaction. Blood bank has
   1 U frozen for this patient and is working to obtain more from the Red
   Cross. DIC labs worsened yesterday.
   - appreciate heme recs: check hemolysis labs daily, guaiac stool ; f/u
   further recs.
   - Continue Procrit, Fe++ po; folate 4mg Qday
   .
   #Coagulopathy: Likely component of shock liver, subacute DIC, and poor
   nutrition. Platelets gradually decreasing over the course of the
   hospital stay. Found to be HIT+ [**4-18**], but SRA negative [**4-23**]. **Pt needs
   separate order for platelet count daily.
   - F/U daily coags and correct INR with vitamin K if has signs of
   bleeding or requires procedure.
   - Follow DIC labs daily. Per heme, if fibrinogen < 100, give cryo.
   Spoke with Blood Bank and Pt should not have issues receiving cryo
   transfusions.
   - Per heme, suspicion for HIT is quite low. Will not anticoagulate with
   argatroban but will hold heparin for now.
   .
   #Left Upper Extremity Swelling: Resolved. No evidence DVT on U/S x 2
   but ?distal stenosis of left subclavian.
   - Continue to monitor strength/sensation/pulses in L arm. No
   intervention at this time.
   .
   #Dysphonia
 due to cuffed 8.0 trach
   - Will hold off changing to smaller cuff until resp status improves
   - ENT consult as needed as outpatient, confirmed with ENT and IP on
   [**2167-4-7**]. Got PMV on [**4-6**].
   .
   #Mental Status: Alert and oriented x 3. Mental status improved today.
   Frustrated with long ICU stay and illness. Continue to monitor as
   pressors are weaned.
   - Frequent reorientation; maintain sleep-wake cycle.
   - Hold Ativan. Use Zyprexa [**Hospital1 **]:PRN for agitation.
   .
   #CV: Stable. CK elevated in the setting of hypovolemia/shock. No
   ischemic EKG changes.  Will recheck CK today given ongoing hypotension.
   CAD: CABG [**2146**] with multiple PCI.  Continue ASA, statin, re-start BB
   when pressures stable.
   PUMP: EF 29%.  Off of pressors, rpt echo EF 25%
   RHYTHM: CHB s/p DDD PCM,ICD in [**2160**]. Not on Warfarin.
   - Maintain on telemetry
   - Maintain Hct >21, ideally >25, but issues with transfusing, see
   above.
   - Continue midodrine, levophed/vasopressin as needed.
   .
   #Tremor: Pt has new resting and action tremor in bilateral hands.
   Differential includes side effect of levophed, neuropathy from chronic
   illness, and ongoing hypocalcemia. Given multiple other issues at this
   time, would not be worthwhile to work up tremor with neurology. Will
   continue to monitor and initiate workup if tremor persists after more
   acute issues resolve.
   .
   FEN
 Holding Tube feeds per G-J tube pending workup of new abd pain.
   Replete lytes PRN.
   PPx
 Pboots, PPI qday. No heparin (HIT+). Foam support for relief of
   pressure ulcer on back of head.
   Code
 DNR. Pressors Ok. Patient already trach
   Access
 HD line, PICC.
   Dispo
 MICU for now
